p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 09:30, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Selection Committee
Report

The SPEAKER (09:31): I present report No. 31 of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation business and private members' business for Monday 24 May 2021. The report will be printed in the Hansard for today and the committee's determinations will appear on tomorrow's Notice Paper. Copies of the report have been placed on the table.
Report relating to the consideration of committee and delegation business and of private Members' business
1. The Committee met in private session on Tuesday, 11 May 2021.

2. The Committee deliberated on items of private Members' business items listed on the Notice Paper and notices lodged on Tuesday, 11 May 2021, and determined the order of precedence and times on Monday, 24 May 2021, as follows:

span.span: Items for House of Representatives Chamber (10.10 am to 12 noon)

p.span: 1 Mr Bandt: To present a Bill for an Act to provide that major emitters of greenhouse gases are liable for climate change damage that occurs in Australia, and for related purposes. (Liability for Climate Change Damage (Make the Polluters Pay) Bill 2021)
(Notice given 23 March 2021.)

span.span: Presenter may speak to the second reading for a period not exceeding 10 minutes—pursuant to standing order 41. Debate must be adjourned pursuant to standing order 142.

p.span: 2 Mr Wilkie: To present a Bill for an Act to establish an independent Commonwealth statutory authority with responsibility for protecting animal welfare in Commonwealth regulated activities, to assist in creating a better Australian animal welfare system, and for related purposes. (Independent Office of Animal Welfare Bill 2021)
(Notice given 11 May 2021.)

span.span: Presenter may speak to the second reading for a period not exceeding 10 minutes—pursuant to standing order 41. Debate must be adjourned pursuant to standing order 142.

p.span: 3 Mr Ted O'Brien: To move:
That this House:
(1) recognises the important work being carried out in Australian businesses to research and commercialise new ideas;
(2) acknowledges that the Government has supported those efforts in many ongoing ways, including:
(a) fostering business collaboration with the CSIRO;
(b) the research and development tax incentive; and
(c) Accelerating Commercialisation grants under the Entrepreneurs Programme; and

(3) congratulates Australian companies that are developing and commercialising new ideas, including Naturo Pty Ltd, which has developed a way to extend the shelf life of fresh milk up to 60 days and is creating a pilot manufacturing facility as a result of its recent Accelerating Commercialisation grant.
(Notice given 22 February 2021.)
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 9 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

p.span: 4 Ms Templeman: To move:
That this House:

(1) notes the devastating effects of extreme rainfall that caused extensive flooding across areas of New South Wales in March 2021, resulting in disaster declarations in 63 local government areas by the NSW Government and causing more than $1billion in damage;
(2) acknowledges the work of emergency services and other groups in assisting throughout the emergency and subsequent clean-up, with particular reference to:
(a) volunteer-based organisations such as the NSW State Emergency Service, NSW Rural Fire Service, Rapid Relief Team, and various charities;
(b) supermarket operators that loaded supplies on to helicopters and barges to restock shelves at stores cut off by flood water and landslides; and
(c) community members who assisted with distribution of supplies and relief efforts during and in the aftermath of the floods; and
(3) calls on the Government to:
(a) provide the support needed to allow businesses reliant on working waterways such as the Hawkesbury River (including turf growers, vegetable farmers and caravan parks) to get back to work;
(b) act to fix the disastrous environmental damage by announcing specific funding to help address silt and debris build up, erosion and collapsing riverbanks; and

(c) immediately access the $4 billion Emergency Response Fund, announced two years ago but never spent, for this recovery which can provide up to $200 million per financial year to be spent nationally on natural disaster recovery and mitigation.
(Notice given 11 May 2021.)

span.span: Time allotted—remaining private Members' business time prior to 12 noon.

p.span: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 9 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.
Items for Federation Chamber (11 am to 1.30 pm)

p.span: 1 Dr Leigh: To move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:

(a) the Euthanasia Laws Act 1997 (known as the Andrews Bill) amended the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978 to deprive these two legislative assemblies of the power to make laws relating to euthanasia;
(b) the Government of Prime Minister Howard justified this at the time as a constraint on young jurisdictions that were seen to be moving ahead of the broader public mood;
(c) when the Andrews Bill curtailed the right of territories to make laws relating to euthanasia, no other state or territory legislature had conducted a debate on similar laws;

(d) polls of public attitudes to doctor-led voluntary assisted dying suggest that support was in the high sixties in the 1980s, in the mid to high seventies in the 1990s, and in the low eighties in the past two decades;

(e) in recent years all state legislatures have debated legislation around voluntary assisted dying, with Victoria and Western Australia legalising voluntary assisted dying, and New South Wales and South Australia rejecting legalisation, while Queensland and Tasmania have processes ongoing;

(f) the anachronistic Andrews Bill means that a quarter of a century since it was passed, 700,000 Australians who live in the Northern Territory or the Australian Capital Territory are still unable to participate in a democratic process to resolve community approaches to euthanasia;
(g) repealing the Andrews Bill would return to territories legal powers that are held by other Australian jurisdictions; and

(h) restoring territory rights does not direct that either territory legislature should consider legislating on euthanasia, it merely allows them to do so if their properly elected representatives decide it appropriate;
(2) acknowledges that:
(a) in each of the last two terms of parliament the Government has blocked debate on private Members' bills that would restore territory rights; and
(b) while senators have debated and voted on related legislation, members of the House of Representatives have been prevented from expressing their views on this issue; and
(3) calls on the Government to:
(a) explain why, in 2021, two mature legislative jurisdictions are still singled out as unworthy of legislative self-determination;
(b) commit to introduce legislation into the House of Representatives that would grant territorians legislative equality with Australians in other jurisdictions; and
(c) restore the right of territories to determine their own laws on euthanasia.
(Notice given 22 February 2021.)
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 7 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

p.span: 2 Mrs Archer: To move:
That this House:
(1) acknowledges that under the Government, we have seen:
(a) a record eight consecutive quarters of year-on-year consumer price index reductions in retail electricity prices; and
(b) wholesale electricity prices fall for 17 months in a row; and
(2) welcomes the Government's strong action to ensure that Australian households and businesses have access to the affordable, reliable and secure electricity.
(Notice given 22 February 2021.)
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 7 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

p.span: Housing: Resumption of debate on the motion of Mr Burns—That this House:
(1) recognises that every Australian should have access to safe and secure housing;
(2) notes that:
(a) the rate of home ownership continues to decline due to this Government's inaction and lack of leadership on federal housing policy;
(b) the rising cost of rent is pushing more Australians into rental stress;
(c) more investment in social housing is needed immediately to address the growing waitlists and increasing number of people facing homelessness; and
(d) the homelessness sector is desperate for more funding to support those needing crisis accommodation, especially women fleeing domestic and family violence; and
(3) calls on the Government to take responsibility and implement policies that respond to the serious issues facing access to safe and secure housing in Australia.
All Members—5 minutes. each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 8 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

p.span: 3 Mr Connelly: To move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:

(a) the Government's $270 billion investment in Australia's defence capability is creating thousands of jobs and opportunities for small businesses across Australia, particularly in the state of Western Australia;

(b) it is only because of the Government's continued investment that we are able to guarantee that the men and women of the Australian Defence Force receive the defence capabilities they need to keep Australians safe; and

(c) a key pillar of our economic recovery plan to get Australians in jobs is getting more Australian businesses in our defence industry to deliver the essential capability our Defence Force relies on; and
(2) recognises that because of the support measures the Government has introduced to help Australian defence:
(a) businesses remain in business and are recovering from COVID-19; and
(b) our defence industry is not only recovering, but thriving as we comeback from the COVID-19 recession.
(Notice given 22 February 2021.)

span.span: Time allotted—remaining private Members' business time prior to 1.30 pm.

p.span: [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 8 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.
Items for Federation Chamber (4.45 pm to 7.30 pm)

p.span: 4 Ms Sharkie: To move—That:

(1) a joint select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Oversight of the Implementation of Recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety be established to inquire into and report upon:

(a) the Government response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission, including the development of a new Act to replace the Aged Care Act 1997 and the establishment and operation of a new person-centred Aged Care system which focuses on the safety, health and wellbeing of older people; and
(b) any matter in relation to the Royal Commission's recommendations referred to the committee by a resolution of either House of the Parliament;
(2) the committee present its final report on or before the final sitting day of the 46th Parliament;
(3) the committee consist of nine members—five senators, and four members of the House of Representatives, as follows:
(a) two members of the House of the Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips;
(b) two members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips;
(c) two senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(d) one senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(e) one senator to be nominated by any minority party or independent senator; and
(f) one member of the House of Representatives nominated by any minority party or independent member;
(4) participating members may:

(a) be appointed to the committee on the nomination of the Government Whip in the House of Representatives, the Opposition Whip in the House of Representatives, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or any minority party or independent senator or member of the House of Representatives; and
(b) participate in hearings of evidence and deliberations of the committee, and have all the rights of members of the committee, but may not vote on any questions before the committee;
(5) every nomination of a member of the committee be notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives;

(6) the members of the committee hold office as a joint select committee until presentation of the committee's final report or until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by effluxion of time, whichever is the earlier;
(7) the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy;
(8) the committee elect:
(a) a Government member as its chair; and
(b) a non-Government member as its deputy chair who shall act as chair of the committee at any time when the chair is not present at a meeting of the committee; and
(c) at any time when the chair and deputy chair are not present at a meeting of the committee, the members present shall elect another member to act as chair at that meeting;
(9) in the event of an equally divided vote, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, shall have a casting vote;

(10) three members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee provided that in a deliberative meeting the quorum shall include one Government member of either House and one non-Government member of either House;
(11) the committee have power to:
(a) appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to examine; and
(b) appoint the chair of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only;

(12) two members of a subcommittee constitute the quorum of that subcommittee, provided that in a deliberative meeting the quorum shall include one Government member of either House and one non-Government member of either House;

(13) the committee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit;

(14) the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives;
(15) the committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public;
(16) the committee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate and the House of Representatives;
(17) the provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders; and
(18) a message be sent to the Senate seeking its concurrence in this resolution.
(Notice given 11 May 2021.)
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 9 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

p.span: 5 Mr Entsch: To move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) Indigenous tourism plays a vital role in supporting businesses, creating jobs and driving economic empowerment of Indigenous Australians;

(b) the Government's $40 million Indigenous Tourism Fund announced on Friday, 19 February 2021 will support Indigenous tourism businesses and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community organisations; and

(c) the establishment of the National Indigenous Tourism Advisory Group will advise the Government on strategic priorities for the growth of Australia's Indigenous tourism sector in a way which best supports the broader tourism sector's recovery; and
(2) recognises and acknowledges that:
(a) Australia's Indigenous culture, country, art and history are unique in today's competitive international tourism market, and are equally attractive to our domestic audience; and

(b) employment in the Indigenous tourism sector provides the opportunity for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians to stay on country while maintaining and sharing their culture and traditions.
(Notice given 22 February 2021.)
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 8 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

p.span: 6 Ms Owens: To move:
That this House:
(1) acknowledges the launch of the Mustafa Kemal Ataturk Bursary on 18 March 2021 at the Australian War Memorial in Canberra;
(2) notes that the bursary is:
(a) a contribution by members of the Australian-Turkish community to the Gallipoli Scholarship, which supports the descendants of Anzacs to study at university or TAFE; and
(b) part of the new Ataturk Scholarship, which will support Turkish Australians to study at university or TAFE from 2022; and

(3) recognises that the donation of this bursary is an act of friendship by Turkish Australians, who have made enormous contributions to our country and community, helping to forge the strong and lasting bond between Australia and Turkey.
(Notice given 11 May 2021.)
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

p.span: 7 Dr Martin: To move:
That this House:
(1) notes that the Government is:
(a) supporting universities through the COVID-19 pandemic and creating more opportunities for young people to study; and
(b) investing $20 billion in the higher education sector in 2021;
(2) recognises that $1 billion has been provided to university research this year;
(3) acknowledges that the Government has provided $903.5 million over the next four years for more domestic places and to ensure our universities are financially stable; and
(4) congratulates the Government for its Job Ready Graduates package which is providing up to 30,000 additional university places in 2021.
(Notice given 22 February 2021.)
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 8 x 5 mins]

span.span: The Committee determined that consideration of this should continue on a future day.

BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Migration Amendment (Tabling Notice of Certain Character Decisions) Bill 2021

p.span: Migration Amendment (Tabling Notice of Certain Character Decisions) Bill 2021
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Hawke.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr HAWKE (Mitchell—Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs) (09:33): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

This bill amends the Migration Act 1958 (the Migration Act) to provide that if the minister makes certain character decisions under subsection 501(3) of the Migration Act in relation to a person, then the minister must cause notice of the making of the decision to be laid before each house of the parliament within 15 sitting days of that house after the day the decision was made.

Decisions made under subsection 501(3) of the Migration Act are those decisions to refuse to grant a visa or to cancel a visa on character grounds that the minister makes personally, without notice to the applicant or visa holder, where the minister considers the refusal or cancellation to be in the national interest.

Requiring notice of the making of certain character decisions under subsection 501(3) of the act to be tabled before each house of parliament will provide greater transparency in relation to the decision to refuse or cancel a person's visa in the national interest on character grounds. Usual tabling practices will be followed, including to ensure that personal information is not published.
This requirement will not apply where the decision was made on the basis the minister reasonably suspects the person does not pass the character test because the person:
has a substantial criminal record; or
has been convicted or found guilty of sexually based offences involving a child; or
has been assessed by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to be directly or indirectly a risk to security.

This requirement will also not apply where the person was the subject of an adverse security assessment or a qualified security assessment under the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 when the decision was made.
All those who support measures to ensure greater transparency and accountability in relation to visa decision-making should support this bill.
I commend the bill to the House.
Debate adjourned.
Leave granted for second reading debate to resume at a later hour this day.

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance Amendment (Income Thresholds) Bill 2021

p.span: Private Health Insurance Amendment (Income Thresholds) Bill 2021
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Tehan, for Mr Hunt.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr TEHAN (Wannon—Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment) (09:36): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The Private Health Insurance Amendment (Income Thresholds) Bill 2021 implements a measure announced in the 2021-22 budget. It will provide continuity for the current policy settings by continuing the pause on the indexation arrangements for income thresholds in the Private Health Insurance Act 2007 for a further two years, and updates the indexation arrangements to apply to the current thresholds from 2023-24. The income thresholds contained in the Private Health Insurance Act 2007 are used in determining the tiers for both the private health insurance rebate and the Medicare levy surcharge. The rebate and surcharge will continue to be income tested.

The government invests over $6 billion each year in the private health insurance rebate which contributes to the affordability of private health insurance for Australians. Following significant reforms over recent years which have made private health insurance simpler and more affordable, the 2021-22 budget sees the Australian government continuing to increase overall spending and investment in health. This includes investing in ongoing reforms to private health insurance which to date have resulted in the lowest annual average premium change for consumers since 2001—2.74 per cent. Specifically in the 2021-22 budget the government is investing $30.6 million over four years to continue to make private health insurance simpler and more affordable for Australians.

Australians continue to rate the quality of health care available in our country at near record high levels but are concerned about the system becoming overstretched. Private health insurance continues to be viewed by Australians as a vital element of the health system, providing choice and helping to relieve pressure on the public system.

The bill supports ongoing reforms in private health insurance. More than half of the Australian population have some form of private health insurance. Income-tested rebate arrangements are a foundation stone of these arrangements and continue under this legislation.

The bill preserves the explicit link between the rebate and the Medicare levy surcharge. It makes no changes to the Medicare levy surcharge rate or the private health insurance rebate rates. This is important as they operate together to ensure that people whose rebates are reduced because of means testing continue to have a strong incentive to retain their private health insurance.

It is important to note that these changes over the next two years will not affect individuals with an income that remains below current base tier thresholds of $90,000, or couples and families with an income that remains $180,000 or below. Higher income earners without private health insurance will continue to be subject to the Medicare levy surcharge.

Importantly the bill will ensure the recommencement of annual indexation from the current income thresholds following the end of the pause, which is important for the continuity of policy settings and predictability for government financing.

This bill provides stability regarding access to the private health insurance rebate and application of the Medicare levy surcharge. During this pause the government will undertake a detailed study into the settings of these two important private health insurance policies to ensure they provide the appropriate incentives for individuals, couples and families when choosing the healthcare cover that best suits their circumstances.
Debate adjourned.
COMMITTEES
Public Works Committee
Reference

Mr TEHAN
( Wannon — Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment ) ( 09:40 ) : On behalf of the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Christmas Island Stormwater, Landslide and Rockfall Mitigation Works Project.

The Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications is proposing to undertake infrastructure works to manage the risks of stormwater flooding, landslide and rockfall at key locations on Christmas Island. Proposed works include upgrades to the stormwater overland flow and in-ground network arrangements at Drumsite, as well as landslide and rockfall defence mitigation and protection measures at Flying Fish Cove.

These proposed works are necessary to protect the community and visitors living or working on Christmas Island and to ensure the government meets its obligations to provide safe workplaces. The estimated cost of the works is $28.9 million excluding GST. The works must be referred, considered by and reported on to both houses of the parliament by the Public Works Committee before work can commence. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction activities are expected to commence in January 2022, with completion expected by mid-2023. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.
Reference
Mr TEHAN (Wannon—Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment) (09:42): On behalf of the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Department of Defence—United States Force Posture Initiatives Northern Territory Training Areas and Ranges Upgrades Project.

The Department of Defence is proposing a project to deliver essential upgrades to facilities and infrastructure at four existing Defence training areas in the Northern Territory to ensure the Australian Defence Force has reliable access to suitable military training areas and weapon ranges to meet military capability. This investment supports implementation of the 2020 Force Structure Plan initiative for enhancements to Defence training areas and facilities. The proposed works will also enhance the levels of interoperability between the Australian Defence Force and our allies, including with United States military forces, through expanded cooperation and increased opportunities for combined training and exercises.

The total estimated capital delivery cost of the project is $747 million. The works must be referred to, considered by and reported on to both houses of parliament by the Public Works Committee before work may commence. Subject to parliamentary approval, the construction works are expected to commence in late 2021 and are scheduled to be completed by mid-2026. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.
Reference
Mr TEHAN (Wannon—Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment) (09:45): On behalf of the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, I move:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Department of Home Affairs—Parramatta office fit-out.

The Department of Home Affairs is proposing fit-out works as part of its consolidation of leased office space in Sydney. Home Affairs currently occupies three buildings in Sydney—two in the Sydney central business district and one in Parramatta. The leases are due to expire in 2022 and 2023, with no options to extend. Under the Home Affairs Sydney precinct strategy, the consolidation of these three sites into a single site in Parramatta will provide operational efficiency and flexibility to allow the change in future business requirements and will reduce overall property operating costs. The estimated costs of the works is $25.2 million. The works must be referred to, considered by and reported on to both houses of the parliament by the Public Works Committee before work may commence. Subject to parliamentary approval, fit-out works are expected to commence in November 2021 and scheduled to be completed in mid-2022. I commend the motion to the House.
Question agreed to.

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and Ministerial responses being presented.

PETITIONS
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (09:47): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, and in accordance with standing order 207, I present the following petitions:
Veterans

This petition by former members of the Royal Australian Navy, Citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House that: Those members serving in HMA Ships during the Vietnam War were exposed to carcinogenic dioxins when contaminated riverine water was distilled to produce potable water which was supposedly fit for human consumption. Sadly, this is not the case. Seven diseases accepted by the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) reflect this concern. Yet five diseases still exist where the DVA do not accept the Factor: 'that must as a minimum exist before it can be said that a reasonable hypothesis has been raised connecting (specific disease) with the circumstances of a person's relevant service is; On land in Vietnam At sea in Vietnamese waters, or On board a vessel and consuming potable water supplied on that vessel when the water supply had been produced by evaporative distillation of estuarine waters for a cumulative period of at least thirty days, at least five years before the clinical onset of (specific disease).'

Your petitioners request the House to: Refer the true circumstances of the above service in Vietnam - and Vietnamese waters - to the Minister concerned, with a recommendation that the following diseases have the Factor quoted inserted into the Statements of Principles for Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Type 2 Diabetes Ischemic Heart Disease Parkinson's Disease Hypothyroidism
from 920 citizens (Petition No. PN0504)
Falun Gong

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that Falun Gong is a peaceful meditation practice based on the principles of Truthfulness, Compassion and Forbearance. Millions of Falun Gong practitioners in China have been fired, jailed, tortured or killed by the Chinese Communist regime since July 1999. There have been persistent reports of systemic, state-sanctioned organ harvesting from non-consenting prisoners of conscience in China, primarily practitioners of Falun Gong. The Independent China Tribunal, chaired by Sir Geoffrey Nice QC, concluded in its Final Judgement in 2019: "Forced organ harvesting has been committed for years throughout China on a significant scale and that Falun Gong practitioners have been one - and probably the main - source of organ supply" and that crimes against humanity against Falun Gong have been proved "beyond reasonable doubt".

We therefore ask the House to request the Prime Minister, Foreign Minister and Australian Government to: 1. Pass a motion or make a statement to openly request an immediate end to the persecution of Falun Gong in China and the immediate release of all Falun Gong practitioners and other prisoners of conscience; 2. Urge China to immediately end the practice of organ harvesting from all prisoners of conscience and conduct a thorough public education campaign to ensure Australians do not unknowingly participate in forced organ harvesting in China; 3. Deny visas and bar entry to Chinese officials and policeman who are involved in the persecution of Falun Gong.
from 551 citizens (Petition No. PN0505)
Housing Affordability
The housing market is currently overpriced due to a number of factors (low interest rates, population growth, Investors/negative gearing benefits, Covid govertment grants being used for deposits etc)
Banks are also allowing an unlimited number of applicants to apply for home loans adding more pressure on the heated market.

Single people are often driven out of the market by couples and couples are often burnt out by having overcommited to a 30 year loan agreement and in most cases mums and dads required to work their whole lives and facing issues such as mental health issues, physical stress and in cases unable to provide sufficient time and care to their children.

There is also a negative effect on the ecomomy as both parties working and contributing 90% of their income to the mortgage and little to none is put back into the ecosystem via spending at businesses etc.

We therefore ask the House to work with APRA and impose restrictions on Lenders to only allow a sole borrower on all loans as this will immediately half the amount being leant and in effect half the price of all houses. This will also free up the second income earner to spend money on the ecomony and stimulate growth or free up more time for family.
This will benefit all Australian citizens as well as the govertment, it will mean less money to be spent on paying parental leave, health care, wellfare, family benefit payments etc.
Thank you
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN2486)
Commonwealth Electoral Act

This petition proposes to grant 16 and 17 year-old Australian citizens the optional right to vote in federal elections. For many older voters, issues such as education can become merely a talking point and nothing more. For younger people however, the quality of our education can greatly affect our future and the people that we become. With our education holding so much influence over our futures, we should have a say in how the education system is run, and the easiest way to do that is by allowing young people to chose who represents their interests in parliament. Education is only an example, as there are many issues such as issues of equality and casual wages that affect many young people, people who ultimately have no say over any policy in these areas. Granting 16 and 17 year olds the right to vote can also increase engagement in our democracy. Ultimately, this change will greatly increase the size of the electorate, which means means more people who get their voices heard, and a parliament that more accurately reflects the people it represents, which can only strengthen our democracy
We therefore ask the House to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 granting 16 and 17 year-old Australian citizens the optional right to vote in all federal elections.
from 81 citizens (Petition No. EN2487)
Child Support Scheme

The Child Support Agency continues to hurt Australian families. The scheme does not represent Australian democratic values of democratic liberalism. Specifically, the scheme reinforces the alienation of fathers from their children post separation. The Child support Scheme manufactures debt and uses draconian measures to collect from payers, who are 85-90% men. Key legislative components used to manufacture debt need to change; such as: 1. Assessing paying parents using their gross income yet collecting from after tax monies 2. Income assessment and change of assessment rules 3. Number of night rules 4. The relevant dependent amount 5. Address all legislative elements that serve to create indirect discrimination toward paying parents. 5. Abolish tax refund interceptions and garnish notices when a payment plan is in place. The scheme has always been controversial and continues to be. Financial coercion is not the answer. The Australian government needs to reflect on its values and its role to libertarian principles of small government. Urgent reform is needed. The Child Support scheme is a failure and needs to be recognised as such and contributes to poor mental health and wellbeing of fathers and is correlated to the high male suicide rates.
We therefore ask the House to take swift and immediate action to save lives and reform/dismantle the child support system.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN2489)
Circumcision

to ban circumcision of all children not just girls. Circumcision is an archaic practice with no practical medical necessity. For boy children it goes back to times when the religious tribes were living in deserts and dry arid lands, circumcision was a necessity because there wasn't enough water for proper hygiene.
We therefore ask the House to ban circumcision of all children, boys and girls.
from 49 citizens (Petition No. EN2490)
Medicare
WHY SHOULD WORKING PEOPLE ON A CERTIAN WAGE OR NOT EMPLOYED BE SUBSIDIZED FOR THEIR HEALTH CARE
EVERONE SHOULD PAY THEIR MEDICARE LEVY (EXCEPT AUST AGED PENSIONERS & AUST, STUDENTS)
We therefore ask the House to MAKE EVERYONE PAY THEIR MEDICARE LEVY & EXEMPT ONLY ALL AUSTRALIAN AGED PENAIONERS & AUST. STUDENTS)
from 9 citizens (Petition No. EN2497)
Extradition Law
Noting that:
the Ministerial response to petition EN2000 stated that "Australia has a robust extradition regime which ensures that criminals cannot evade justice simply by crossing borders"

Australia's extradition system currently detains Australian citizens without trial in Australia for actions alleged to have occurred entirely within Australia and who have never been convicted of any offence and are not criminals and who have never crossed any border to evade justice.

We therefore ask the House to amend the Extradition Act so as to confine its application to "criminals evading justice by crossing borders" and require Australian Citizens to be tried in Australia for allegations of criminal conduct which are said to have occurred in Australia.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN2499)
COVID-19: Remembrance Day

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a domestic and international disaster, with millions of lives lost across the world, jobs and livelihoods destroyed, and untold effects on people's mental health, education and social/cultural lives.

As a reminder of the lives lost, and the sacrifices people made to contain the pandemic, but also as a symbol of hope for what we can do together when we all pull together toward a common goal, we propose that a National Day of Remembrance be declared for COVID-19.

There a many days on the calendar that could be chosen: The first case in Australia, the day of the first death, the day the Ruby Princess arrived. But as a day of hope and hard work, a day that already has special meaning, for everything that the people of Victoria sacrificed, we propose that 26 October - "Doughnut Day" - be declared as COVID-19 Remembrance Day.

A day to remember who we lost, what we missed out on, the efforts of our health workers and frontline workers at the borders and quarantine hotels, people who chose to spend 14+ days in locked room to visit family, people who lost jobs, the unexpected improvements like working from home, and how we all together managed to make it through.
A day to eat a doughnut, 'get on the beers', and remember 2020 -2021.
We therefore ask the House to declare 26 October as National COVID-19 Remembrance Day - to be colloquially known as Doughnut Day.
from 5 citizens (Petition No. EN2502)
Australian Consumer Law
Consumer Guarantees under the ACL (Australian Consumer Law) were not applicable during the pandemic.

Customers lost the Consumer Guarantee for a refund for services not provided when their travel bookings were cancelled due to COVID-19 and had to interpret "force majeure" clauses and argue Frustrated Contracts and Undue Enrichment.
At an industry level, travel companies and industry bodies lobbied to restrict credit card charge backs lodged by customers to obtain their funds.

At an individual level, many Australians have resorted to arguing their case at State Civil and Administrative Tribunals. Faced with well resourced travel companies, not all consumers have the capability to advocate for their refund entitlements. Despite a contractual right to refund, the effort required to secure refunds is beyond customers who have endured job losses, serious medical conditions and terminal illness.

Post-Covid, many travel providers having created new terms and conditions that preclude cash refunds. Consumers that hold credits for existing travel booking are concerned that credits are not guaranteed, insured or protected in trust from insolvency.
The EU and US have legislated to provide consumers with refunds in the event of travel cancellations. Australian customers seek similar legislative protections.

We therefore ask the House to include a provision in the Australian Consumer Law for the right to a refund for consumers in the event a supplier does not comply with consumer guarantees, due to a cause independent of human control.
from 1566 citizens (Petition No. EN2504)
Charitable Organisations
Stop charity and organizations and businesses continue to email and call asking for money
We therefore ask the House to bring in legislation to stop continue harassment from charity and business email and calling asking for money
from 6 citizens (Petition No. EN2506)
Ethiopia

On November 4, 2020, the Ethiopian government led by Abiy Ahmed Ali declared war on the Tigray Region. Since then, the Ethiopian federal army and allied forces from the Amhara region, along with the Eritrean army have waged an atrocious war on Tigray that has forced over 2.2 million people to flee their homes, with over 61,000 civilians fleeing to neighbouring Sudan. The atrocities include: 1) Indiscriminate shelling, civilian massacres, and extrajudicial killing 2) Weaponized hunger - Weaponized sexual and gender-based violence against women and girls 3) Destruction of UNESCO world heritage sites and mass looting. Australia's bilateral relations with Ethiopia have been active for 56 years. Ethiopia has been represented by an ambassador in Canberra since December 2013. An ambassador of whom is indirectly endorsing the state-sponsored genocide in Tigray by remaining silent.

We therefore ask the House to 1) Take a public stance against the war crimes, weaponized sexual violence, restricted humanitarian access and foreign troops in the Tigray region of Ethiopia. 2) Advocate and push for unhindered and unrestricted humanitarian access to Tigray. 3) Request an independent investigation into potential war crimes, crimes against humanity and other detrimental actions taken place in the Tigray region of Ethiopia, since November 4, 2020. 4) Call for the immediate removal of foreign Eritrean troops and Amhara militia in Tigray. 5) Assist the international community, including their friend, the United States in the cessation of all hostilities in Tigray.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN2510)
Working Holiday Maker Program
-Visa holders met all the requirements when they lodge their applications.

- The travel restrictions imposed by the Australian government made it impossible for any foreigner to enter the country. Under the current legislation, it is established that visa holders have 12 months to enter Australia since their visas are granted. The time to enter the country should not be running as in normal circumstances if borders are closed. Visas should still be valid because it was not a matter of personal choice not to travel but a precaution to protect everybody's health.

- WHV makers represent a workforce and an important ally in order to boost tourism and help the economy thrive after this sanitary crisis and should not be excluded for having exceeded the age limit since that happened after the granting of the visas.

- WHV holders have spent a lot of resources to prepare for this project. It is not fair that the only solution is to get a refund when visas were legitimately granted by the Australian government before the outbreak of this unforeseeable crisis.
- WHV holders are people willing to work and spend money in the country, pay taxes and contribute to the economy.
We therefore ask the House to extend the working holiday visas that were granted before the outbreak of Covid19 regardless of the candidates' age.
from 2917 citizens (Petition No. EN2434)
COVID-19: Pacific Islands

Australia as a regional power in the Pacific has the duty to provide support for the developing countries in the Pacific region. Further more, Pacific Island workers are a key part of our farming industry, providing valuable labour on seasonal harvesting. Some Pacific countries may not have capability or the financial mean to source sufficient vaccine for their entire population. In providing Covid-19 vaccine to the full population of all Pacific island countries, not only Australia will show our regional leadership, it is also in our best interest to secure a reliable workforce. Furthermore travel bubble can be developed to allow for quarantine free travel within the Pacific region.

We therefore ask the House to consider supplying Covid-19 Vaccine as well as providing logistic support to all Pacific Island nations to ensure their entire population can be vaccinated and to remove any export requirement (if any) for the vaccine. This is with the intention to allow for have a quarantine free travel within the Pacific region.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN2436)
Tobacco Taxation
We, the citizens of Australia, Request that the House to lower the excess tobacco tax that is pushing people to poverty and also helping a dangerous black market open up and spread far and wide.
We therefore ask the House to lower the tobacco tax to a reasonable that all Australians can agree on.
from 34 citizens (Petition No. EN2437)
Minister for Defence

In December 2019 petition EN1199 was put to parliament and never passed on to a minister for response. Mr O'Brien said the petition was too similar to petition EN0963. EN1199 relates to the 2019 election and EN0963 to the 2016 election.

EN0963 relied on information from the solicitor general, the same solicitor general who got it so wrong with Mr Joyce and a dozen or more MPs. The Crown Solicitor noted they were not given very much information from Mr Dutton.

In February 2019 Mr Dutton declared he was a beneficiary of RHT family trust in his Register of Members Interests. At the same time the ABN data base lists two companies as being the responsibility of RHT family trust, CAMELIA AVENUE CHILDCARE CENTRE and BALD HILLS CHILDCARE CENTRE. The Department of Finance list both of these companies as recipients of Commonwealth funding. After the election Mr Dutton declared he had "renounced" his family trust and was not a beneficiary. Mr Dutton's wife and children are beneficiaries of the trust and the Commonwealth money given to that trust through the two child care centres. Because his family still benefit that is an indirect pecuniary interest in that trust. The house can not determine if an MP has or hasn't breached the constitution, that can only be determined by the High Court.
We therefore ask the House to refer Mr Dutton to the High Court as per S47, the directions given in Mr Gillespie's case, which were not implemented.
from 83 citizens (Petition No. EN2439)
Azerbaijan
Armenia

In the 1990s Armenian occupying forces expelled 700,000 Azerbaijanis from Nagorno-Karabakh and seven surrounding districts. Before that, 200,000 Azerbaijanis were expelled from Armenia. Four UN resolutions reaffirmed the territorial integrity of Azerbaijan and demanded immediate withdrawal of Armenian forces from the occupied territories of Azerbaijan. Armenia had been ignoring these resolutions for 30 years. Following the recent counteroffensive operation Azerbaijan restored its territorial integrity. Currently Russian peacekeeping mission is monitoring the ceasefire regime in Nagorno-Karabakh.

Several Australian state politicians (NSW and SA) have voted for anti-Azerbaijani/Turkish motions full of distortions, unfounded claims and strong biased emotive language, aimed at skewing the reality of the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict. Instead of dealing with the immediate needs of their constituents, the state governments are debating issues that are outside their responsibilities.

As Australians of Azerbaijani/Turkish origin, we feel vulnerable, marginalised, and threatened. We don't want a distant regional conflict to affect our lives and the lives of our children in our new home. We don't want to participate in unnecessary political confrontations or battles with our fellow Australians of Armenian origin. We want to be assured that no Australian politician is influenced by the Armenian Nationalistic narrative, and will demonise us, our ethnicity, and our countries of origin. Our children's lives, employment opportunities, social interactions should not be threatened by a toxic non-Australian attitude created by a nationalistic diaspora.
We therefore ask the House to condemn divisive racist harmful and discriminatory political rhetoric contradicting Australian political stance and promoting agenda of nationalistic ethnic group.
from 2014 citizens (Petition No. EN2441)
Department of Veterans' Affairs

The Department of Veteran Affairs has a 11% attrition rate and 42% of staff are on 3-to-6-month contracts. There is nowhere near enough permanent delegates to compile, manage or complete the complexity of existing claims or request for services. This is causing a serious delay in all facets of aiding veterans and increases stress placed upon both Veterans, Current Serving ADF Members and Delegates is overwhelming. DVAs own internal analysis found that for every 100 claims accepted there are on average 60 high impact errors, Source Figures supplied by DVA under FOI 2020.

We therefore ask the House to to increase Department of Veteran Affairs Delegate numbers 50% in the governments financial budget 2021 /2022 and continue forward for permanent Delegates to be employed within Department of Veteran Affairs.
Ex Members of the Secretaries round Table.
from 120 citizens (Petition No. EN2442)
COVID-19: Vaccination

To alleviate the issues with regard to transmission of Covid 19 and it's variants it is put forward that the only real way to ensure the safety of all Australians is to make the vaccine or any subsequent vaccine compulsory unless there is an underlying medical reason that a person may not be able to have such vaccine, e,g, in life threatening circumstances. This would include not just residents of Australia and its Territories but also all visitors including diplomatic persons.

We therefore ask the House to put forward the relevant legislation to ensure that the petition's requirements are met to the fullest. That such legislation should ensure that vaccination for Covid 19 and it's variants should subsequent vaccines become available are made compulsory for all Australians whether citizens, residents or visitors including diplomatic, military, business or tourists. The only exception should be where an underlying medical condition restricts the use of the vaccine for a specific individual. Race, beliefs and religion should not be a deterrent nor reason not to receive the vaccination.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. EN2444)
COVID-19: Vaccination

The public is concerned about the safety and efficacy of the synthetic m-RNA COVID vaccines. This is a new technology, never used before. This brings two areas of concern; 1) their effectiveness, and 2) their safety.

There is no clear evidence that those 'vaccines' are effective. The m-RNA in the 'vaccines' is allegedly protected against the natural body enzymes that break m-RNA's (RNA-ases). Whilst the American CDC assures the public that they don't enter the nucleus of cells to change the DNA, their resistance to these enzymes means that they can persist in cells indefinitely. In effect, the outcome of such longevity is similar to changing the DNA. Furthermore, the synthetic m-RNA in the 'vaccines' can enter sex cells, passing down adverse side effects to future generations. The Swiss and other governments have banned, restricted and/or are reconsidering their use.
We therefore ask the House to immediately suspend the use of m-RNA 'vaccines' in Australia until there is enough scientific evidence to prove the following:
1.That they are effective in creating immunity against COVID-19.

2.That the suppliers/manufacturers provide adequate independent scientific proof that the synthetic m-RNA in the 'vaccines' is safe, does not have RNA-ase blockers and that it cannot pass on side effects to future generations
from 956 citizens (Petition No. EN2445)
NAPLAN: Eid al-Fitr

We would like the government of Australia to consider change of dates for NAPLAN as the date clashes with festival of Eid Al Fitr for the Muslims of Australia (after the holy month of Ramadan fasting from dawn to dusk) that is on 12th or the 13th May 2021 which happens to be the same dates for NAPLAN. Almost every household would have a child in Grade 3,5, 7 or 9. Our festival starts with a prayer in the morning after sunrise which students will miss if they have to attend school for NAPLAN. It has been a quite festival even last year due to COVID. A consideration to change dates would be highly appreciated by all muslim citizens of Australia.
We therefore ask the House to consider change of dates for NAPLAN
from 1442 citizens (Petition No. EN2448)
India

Ever since the implementation of progressive farm bills by the Indian government, certain separatist groups within the Indian state and also within Australia have been threatening the Indian Australian community who support these farm bills. Social media threats, Physical assault, hate speech and instigating violence has been the main motive of these agitators who carry out their protest in the name of "peaceful protests". Cases of the same has been reported in Sydney of physical assault and in Melbourne that of a threat. Banned terrorist organisation 'babbar khalsa' has sent threats to Indian Australians for supporting the farm bills which has also been reported by the recipients. These agitators are in large numbers residing within Australia and their behaviour has concerned many Indian Australians over the past few months.

We therefore ask the House to cease any funding and permission to protest to these separatist groups as they have ill intentions for Indian-Australian and are spreading disharmony with the Australian community. We also hope that strict legal action is taken against any separatist individual or groups for violent behaviour against Indian-Australians and all the Indian-Australian institutions.
from 3 citizens (Petition No. EN2449)
Democratic Republic of Congo
This petition from residents of Australia, who are members and supporters of Voice for Silent People, draws to the attention of the House:

The war has been going on in the Democratic Republic of Congo since 1996. The main cause of this war is the illegal exploitation of minerals such as coltan and cobalt needed to manufacture technological devices such as smartphones, iPads and computers. As a consequence, people in Congo are victims of serious crimes against humanity. Several civilian populations have been displaced or massacred; more than five million people have been killed; children are subject to slave-like labour conditions and women are being raped. The progress of technology means that cobalt will be in high demand in the near future. Some developed countries are planning to fabricate only electrical cars from 2030. Electrical cars will need rechargeable batteries made with cobalt. More than half of the cobalt used in the world comes from the DRC. This future demand for cobalt constitutes a high risk of increased atrocities against local populations in Congo. The only way to prevent this is to have past crimes punished and victim's rights restored.
We therefore ask the House to:

Support the formation of an International Tribunal under United Nations to investigate crimes against humanity committed since the beginning of the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo so as to obtain justice for victims and fair punishment for criminals.
from 137 citizens (Petition No. EN2451)
National Education Standards

Science by joint-effort; has discovered a true passage for all Human-Cultures to go forward together, "In a common direction; Yes! Scientifically refusing to lie, Discriminate, or deceive our Children in any way, informs us; Politically and legally using "Human-Evolution Education" will design a legal moral-code to govern the conduct of human-affairs. So let's remember our belief and faith in all Children, as they become excited in going to School, having 'pleasurable anticipation' to be Educated about how they 'Evolved' over Millions of years.

We therefore ask the House to debate this 'EDUCATION BILL: Australian Education Act 2013; to make this proposed legislation into law. Part 1: Introduce one Subject. (Human-Evolution Education) Compassionately touched and designed for 'ALL' Students in 'EVERY' Australia School-culture; which will build a high-quality early Childhood Education for those Students, on their journey through School, and University: Part 2: Introduce one (H-E.E.L. HUMAN-EVOLUTION EDUCATION LAW) holding mandate authority if-required, over one (Compulsory Separate Curriculum) in grades 1 to 12, for all students in all culture to receive the Scientific Proven-Facts about, "How they Evolved." Part 3: Introduce (The Human-Evolution Book of Knowledge) to all Students in all cultures; means, teaching or preaching 'god' is a living-thing, and Humans never Evolved, will be banned from all Schools, other buildings and elsewhere. Or, hold a referendum: (Vote YES, Human-Evolution Education) (Vote NO, Human-Evolution Education)
from 1 citizen (Petition No. EN2452)
COVID-19: International Travel

Almost 12 months ago Australia Citizens had one of their civil rights taken away. The ban on all international travel into and out of Australia was put in place to "flatten the curve." While at that time we did not have much information about the COVID-19 virus, twelve months on, we have now learned that 99% of cases of the virus are asymptomatic, and with two vaccines approved for use that have been deemed effective at preventing severe cases of the disease, there is now no reason for the international travel ban to remain.

We therefore ask the House to remove the ban on international travel by June 1st (at the latest.) This date is important as by that time we will have near 10 million doses of various vaccines either administered or available to those people who are most at risk of contracting severe symptoms of COVID-19. With this in mind, we would not be running the risk of our hospitals becoming overrun, and those who do fall ill with the disease will be able to be treated.

There comes a point that the large majority of the population who will be asymptomatic if they contract the disease, should not have to sacrifice their basic freedom of movement RIGHT to protect a very small minority.
from 109 citizens (Petition No. EN2453)
Media

The Australian news, of which is predominately owned by Rupert Murdoch is constantly spreading dangerous and ill informed misinformation of which could potentially be dangerous to the public. The general platforms that the fear mongering posts are instagram, Twitter and most famously; Facebook. It is a general public safety matter when for example: Friday, February 26 2020 7 news released an article about 99 suburbs being on high alert for corona virus whilst the Queensland and federal governments have had absolutely no statements for such. This kind of misinformation is dangerous and could do more harm for the public then good.

We therefore ask the House to remove news outlets from the far right to the far left from social media platforms and to closely regulate the ill formed scare smear related content that they pump out. It's for a happy, healthier and most importantly a dagger community.
from 2 citizens (Petition No. EN2454)
Energy
Unlike the Australian government,, many foreign governments put basic necessities before ideological causes championed by UN bureaucrats.
Australian people never voted for radical climate action with Rudd or Shorten.

$3.4 trillion invested in renewables this decade, why are the world's most rapidly growing economies still powering their factories with coal, and why did wind turbines and solar panels only produce 9% of the world's power in 2020?

If they are so cheap and efficient, why are they subsidised by the taxpayer, and why do they get feed-in priority into the grid, meaning they don't compete with coal, gas, hydro and other forms of generation on the same footing?

And if climate change is such a threat why isn't the United Nations going after the CCP which is building 127 coal-fired power stations and allowed to increase its emissions to 2030 under the Paris Agreement?

workers in mining, farming and energy-intensive industry & many Australians know an industrial economy can't thrive without reliable, affordable baseload power, the likes of which renewables are incapable of providing.
We therefore ask the House to STOP SUBSIDZING SOLAR & WIND ENERGIES & ALLOW FEDERAL GOV. TO & BUSINESSES TO BUILD NEW LOW EMISSION COAL POWER
Energy policy makers need to stop the rhetoric and deliver on what majority of Australians voted & asked for at the last election:
common-sense economic management; cheap, reliable power; and reindustrialisation via infrastructure development, without subsidies and hype about unproven technologies.
We demand BACK to cost-competitive industrial base.
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN2457)
Pesticides

I, the undersigned citizen of Australia draw to the attention of the House that I know that it is my duty to keep you informed of my will on any matter that comes before the parliament or that should come before the parliament. I give notice to Members of the House of Representatives of the systemic regulatory failure to protect humans, animals and the environment from toxic and polluting pesticides.
We therefore ask the House to note that it is the will of each individual signatory that Members of the House of Representatives initiate and support the following:
1. Royal Commission on the Australian Pesticides Regulation System and evident failure to protect humans, animals and the environment from toxic and polluting pesticides.
2. Moratorium on the use of pesticides causing chemical trespass, environmental pollution and adverse effects:
a) spraying pesticides in urban areas: footpaths, laneways, verges, schools, parks, reserves, roadsides...
b) spraying pesticides on public and private land near organic and biodynamic farms.
3. Moratorium on the sale of pesticides in the absence of quality and hazard assessment by the Australian Regulator.
4. Government Support Package for victims of Regulatory failure to prevent foreseeable harm and loss
from 163 citizens (Petition No. EN2458)
Parliament

Petition EN1252 asked that MPs be reminded of their obligation under APH Information sheet 15 to "communication skills are important in all aspects of a Member's work, but are particularly so in working with constituents"

That petition was given to Mr Porter to respond to in March 2020. He didn't bother, instead he re-wrote Information sheet 15 taking those words "communication skills are important in all aspects of a Member's work, but are particularly so in working with constituents" out of the new information sheet. Petition EN1252 still hasn't been answered and is inappropriate now Mr Porter has changed Information sheet 15.
We therefore ask the House to rewrite Information Sheet 15 to include the words:-

"communication skills are important in all aspects of a Member's work, but are particularly so in working with constituents and especially with social media and email correspondence. MPs should be reminded not to block constituents from trying to contact them on social media or via email and should endeavour to answer their questions and queries on these modern forms of communication "
from 7 citizens (Petition No. EN2459)
Australian Currency

In recent years, cryptocurrency has been gaining more and more traction. Online operations, how to buy, sell bitcoin, exchange cryptocurrency - in the modern world, in the world of Digital technologies, no one is surprised anymore. And after the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, this topic has become especially acute and relevant.
We therefore ask the House to consider the legalization of cryptocurrencies
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN2461)
COVID 19: Vaccination

We want the Government to commit to not rolling out any e-vaccination status/immunity passport to the Australian public. Such passports could be used to restrict the rights of people who have refused a Covid-19 vaccine, which would be unacceptable and discriminatory.
More details

The Australian Government has plans despite reports that people who have received the Covid-19 vaccine will be offered a passport proving they have been vaccinated as part of a government-funded trial. Citizens who refuse will not have the documentation to freely travel, giving automatic discrimination to only enter countries that accept only documented civilians.

We therefore ask the House to be completely clear to the public about the use of vaccine passports & their intentions, they must refuse the roll-out of it because of those who will decline and their fundemental basic rights being violated by this legislation. Simply by segregating the "immune" and "non-immune" We implore the House to change the law to not include this as a pre-requisite for travel or for any of its other associated relevant potential uses. As the e-vaccination/immunity passport enforcement of this policy or practice will lead to the segregation of the Australian people of different races, classes, or ethnic groups, as in schools, housing, and public or commercial facilities, especially as a form of discrimination if you do not have one simply because of their personal decision.
This decision which will undoubtedly affect societal cohesion. Discriminating via a passport which is a person's identity is wrong.
from 63339 citizens (Petition No. EN2463)
Pensions and Benefits
I am requesting that all pension payments be increased to be equal to the minimum wage for a person 21 years of age.
We therefore ask the House to raise all pension payments to be equal to the minimum wage of $753.80 per week.
from 173 citizens (Petition No. EN2464)
Foreign Investment

The Chinese company China Bloom has a lease on Keswick Island in the Whitsundays region of Queensland, the locals have repeatedly made claims and have reported that the company has posted security guards around the island and have been repeatedly approached and questioned by the private security group hired by China Bloom.

The locals of the area have also reported that Australians have been banned by the company China Bloom from using public boat ramps, stopping citizens from visiting public beaches, shutting down the local airstrip, and posted signs around the island claiming public areas as private property.
A foreign entity that is found to be committing such actions and dictating the access of public areas to Australians is to forfeit Australia's sovereignty to that land.

We therefore ask the House to investigate the claims of the local Australians of the Keswick Island area and to cancel the Lease of the Chinese company China Bloom has on the island under security concerns and of sovereignty concerns should these claims be proven true.
from 68 citizens (Petition No. EN2468)

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology

p.span: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology
The fact that the police are not pursuing the matter for practical reasons does not preclude or prevent the Prime Minister from undertaking an inquiry into a very serious allegation.
the justice system in this instance had failed all parties involved.

There is a strong argument that the justice system has failed not only the alleged victim, but Christian Porter, because he has not been given the opportunity to be interviewed by police, to provide an affidavit, to have witnesses come forward.
Christian Porter has a right to the presumption of innocence. So, let him give sworn evidence.

A coronial inquiry is never going to rule on criminal matters but it would provide an opportunity for him to give his version of events for a coroner to ask him questions about it and to ask questions about why this woman was released after she'd been under medical care, and then forced, as I understand it, to be quarantined at home for two weeks.
Morrison would represent the interests of a dead woman who was violated - and the friends who believed her.

Morrison would also represent the interests of his attorney general, who says he is innocent, and would be benefitted by an orderly and transparently fair process where he is able to defend his reputation.
Morrison should constitute an independent coronial inquiry.
We therefore ask the House to formally demand an independent inquiry into Christian Porter's rape allegations and the surrounding toxic and misogynistic culture of the Australian Parliament.
from 57 citizens (Petition No. EN2470)

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology

p.span: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology

Request for Independent Inquiry into historic allegations against Christian Porter, to reassure the public that he is fit for office and restore the peoples' trust. Also for Mr Porter's own mental wellbeing - to know that he is exonerated in the court of public opinion.
We therefore ask the House to initiate an Independent Inquiry into the historic rape allegations against the Attorney General Christian Porter MP.
from 2340 citizens (Petition No. EN2472)
Media
All news media in Australia receiving government tax relief, subsidies or contracts in excess of $1m per year have an obligation to give free access to all digital news media they produce.

We therefore ask the House to bring forth amendments to the News Media Bargaining Code that requires any news media outlet receiving government subsidies, tax reliefs or contracts in excess of $1m per financial year to remove all forms restriction on digital news media. This will give all Australians fair and free access to all digital news media publications allowing them to make more informed decisions in their every day life.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN2473)
Afghanistan

According to its Constitution, Afghanistan is a nation that respects the rule of law, social justice, protecting integrity and human rights, and attaining peoples' freedoms and fundamental rights. The Australian Government has supported Afghanistan through decades of war. Still, as peace talks seek to end the violence, hundreds of Afghan human rights defenders, journalists, and media workers have been deliberately targeted and killed. These attacks undermine the importance of freedom of speech, human rights, and the foundation of a lawful society.

The protection of Afghan women fulfilling professional roles in society is also a concern and the protection of women in general. Afghan women lawyers, judges, educators, students, political analysts, civil servants are extremely vulnerable. Many have already been displaced from their roles in several provinces or killed. The deliberate killing of civilians is contrary to international humanitarian law and may amount to war crimes. The Afghan people deserve the protections afforded to them by international treaties and conventions as a human right.

We therefore ask the House to call on the Australian Government to publicly condemn the violence against Afghan human rights defenders, journalists and media workers, and especially violence against Afghan women in these and other roles in society. We ask the Australian Government to increase its support to the Afghanistan Government by providing urgent and immediate protections for Afghanis in these roles, and to protect their legitimate rights to life, freedom of expression, to access education, employment and other fundamental freedoms without fear of reprisal or attack.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN2474)
Marine Arctic Peace Sanctuary

For millions of years, the frozen Arctic Ocean kept our world's weather patterns balanced, ensuring we all have the food and water we need to survive. But the oldest and thickest sea ice has declined by 95%. In its wake are emerging threats like buried pathogens and methane in nearby permafrost, that could sicken us all and/or destroy our global economy. In addition, businesses perceive Arctic open waters as pathways for oil and gas, fishing, militarization and shipping, without understanding the true cost of doing so in natural disasters, food shortages, refugees, economic and political turmoil, and mass extinction. Antarctica has been protected from exploitation for decades by the Antartica Treaty system. According similar protection to the North Pole, the Marine Arctic Peace Sanctuary Treaty transforms the Arctic Ocean into the world's largest preservation area for the benefit of all life. No region, nation, or species is separate in our world. All life is interconnected and interdependent, and as such, there is no such thing as "someone else's problem". This has become clearer than ever in light of the global coronavirus pandemic. All human lives, including those of Australian citizens, are at risk due to the loss of the Arctic ice and the impending exploitation of the Arctic Ocean.

We therefore ask the House to recommend Australia's formal endorsement of the Marine Arctic Peace Sanctuary Treaty on an urgent basis, to protect the citizens and ecosystems of Australia, and all life on Earth.
from 47 citizens (Petition No. EN2481)
COVID-19: International Travel

The government has extended the travel ban and have also put heavy restrictions on who can enter the country. This still means, extended family members that are currently overseas, mostly parents, cannot visit their children and grandchildren living in Australia.

There are many countries that have accelerated the COVID vaccination process and have allowed their citizens to get vaccinated. These countries are providing the same vaccine (Pfizer and AZ) that Australia has signed up to provide to its citizens. If people have got the vaccine then why should they be banned from traveling to Australia? Why isn't the government considering a process where they can allow citizens who have received a vaccination to travel to Australia? We can still follow negative COVID test 72 hrs before travel and test on arrival.
We therefore ask the House to consider allowing extended family members who have already got the COVID vaccine to travel to Australia, if they can provide proof of vaccination.
from 2501 citizens (Petition No. EN2485)
Australian Defence Force

There is no good conduct medals for ADF members, unlike civilian agencies such as the Emergency Services. Emergency services members must complete 6 years of good conduct in order to receive these , Many of which do. ADF members receive little recognition for performance, medals of merit are uncommon, especially in the low to mid ranks, which members could be serving in for over 15 years. Jubilee medals are available to all members of the commonwealth, serving at the time of jubilee or coronation events. Australia has declined to issue these to service members, except on special circumstances.

We therefore ask the House to consider the issue of jubilee medals to serving ADF veterans , whether it be under the normal conditions of the issuance of the medal, or as a recognition of good conduct, as already exists in the civilian services
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN2401)
Child Support Scheme

Leaving a violent relationship takes great courage, strength and determination. It takes time to establish a secure, stable future often whilst grappling with safety fears and mental health issues. Unfortunately, there are currently gaps within federal legislation that enable perpetrators to use Child Support as a tool for ongoing financial abuse. In too many cases, the regular payment requirements are not met and arrears accumulate.

Although the Child Support Agency (CSA) possesses the authority to recover registered debt from the payer's salary, wage or social security benefits, there are significant delays in the Agency actually taking such administrative action. In order to protect those entitled to frequent child support payments and create a system incapable of being exploited as a means of financial abuse, it is necessary to impose circumstances requiring mandatory administrative enforcement.
We therefore ask the House to set:
1. A quantitative limit on the number of late payments allowable before the CSA is mandated to garnish payer's income streams thus ensuring full, regular payments.

2. A quantitative limit on the amount of child support arrears ($5,000) that can accumulate before the CSA is mandated to recover these arrears by all means necessary unless the payer submits a formal application for consideration of extenuating circumstances.

3. Authority for the CSA to declare arrears a legally recoverable debt, and state the CSA is required to do so if no substantive and reasonable attempt to repay the debt has been taken 6 months after the arrears began to accumulate.
from 89 citizens (Petition No. EN2402)
COVID-19: Aviation Industry

Although the vast majority of the economy is experiencing a strong V shaped recovery, the Aviation Industry continues to be the subject of extensive restrictions and volatility. Government agencies have signalled that the closure of international borders will likely continue further into late 2021 and possibly beyond, despite the impending vaccine roll out.

International border closures, although effective against the virus, have caused an almost total collapse of the aviation sector and restricted our ability to trade. These closures have only been compounded by the patch work approach to opening and closing of state and territory borders over the past 6 months.
As the industry first effected by the pandemic and likely the last to be unimpeded; our industry is uniquely disadvantaged, and our recovery will no doubt move at a different pace.
