Recently the industry, in a joint open letter, has urged the Prime Minister to extend JobKeeper payments for aviation workers and to continue to support the industry until we can operate without restriction.

It is our firm belief that we are a resourceful and essential industry sector which provides stable and long term employment to its workers and are the backbone of economic growth in Australia, but while borders are closed our ability to operate as a viable and sustainable industry is smothered and restricted.
We therefore ask the House to implore the Government to provide support to our employees by either extending JobKeeper or by offering a specific Aviation Industry wage subsidy and rescue package.
from 321 citizens (Petition No. EN2404)
COVID-19: Quarantine

Stuck in another lockdown. Hotel quarantine failure again. Federal government to immediately use all offshore and remote locations for international arrivals. Manus, Nairu, Xmas etc. Fly in to Oz only when negative Covid. Don't care the logistics, Scomo do your job and keep us safe. Stop spectating!

We therefore ask the House to Immediately make all resources available for mandatory FEDERAL 14 day quarantine at remote and offshore locations. Stop using 'logistics' as an excuse. Compare the logistical issues and damage of all Aussies and business of open then closed borders, ever changing restrictions, close contact quarantining. Feds can and should fix this. It is their job.
from 9 citizens (Petition No. EN2407)
COVID-19: Quarantine

Australian States (and in particular, the Victorian State Government), seem incapable of handling quarantine of international arrivals, as they so casually send our lives into chaos, within a moment's notice!

Border control & security are the Federal government's responsibility (see Australian Constitution - Section 51(ix) ), and our State leaders have reaffirmed their inability to manage this vital step in keeping all Australians safe!!

We therefore ask the House to handle all quarantine at a federal facility, as was done with the cruise ship people back at the beginning, we wouldn't have staff getting the virus and taking it home and into the community. The military would handle the lot, and our lives could continue to function reasonably normally, without lock-downs and unnecessary State Border closures.

We plead with you, to see the sense in this and that "For the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth", you take over this mess at a Federal level. We the people are tired of unnecessary State border closures and the removal of freedoms and our Common Law rights.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN2408)
COVID-19: Vaccination

People do not need to believe what the government and their bureaucrats declare to be true, there are always many sides to the story, members of parliament have been silenced by attacks from the media, Australian citizens expressing alternative views have been shut down by various forms of media. Democracy is broken.

We therefore ask the House to to approve a study investigating the following statement "There are anti-vaxxers, there are vaccine hesitant people, there are pro-vaxxers, there are vaxx-mongers. Statistics pertaining to Covid infection and deaths around the world are based on what happens within 28 days of what has happened after the human had tested positive to SARS-COV-2 since December 2019. It was not known what caused the illness or the death. The only possible way of ensuring that people are confident of the associated vaccines is to apply the same standard. The Australian government should provide the outcomes of Covid-vaccinated citizens within 28 days of receiving the vaccine for the same period of 15 months before making any legislation, or making any rule that infringes civil rights or the Geneva convention. We deserve our choice as citizens of a democracy to have informed consent.
from 101 citizens (Petition No. EN2409)
Road Safety
In 2020, 173 Australian workers were killed at work,
51 of those were Professional Truck Drivers serving Australia,
9 Australian workers have been killed at work so far in 2021 According to Safe Work Australia,
The Truck Drivers of Australia Deserve Recognition of Their Sacrifices

We therefore ask the House to: Launch a Royal Commission to investigate the ongoing fatalities of Truck Drivers who are designated "Essential Workers" as a matter of National Importance, and Report the link between The Current Road Safety Outcomes and the Repeal of The Road Safety Remuneration Act 2012
from 399 citizens (Petition No. EN2410)
Telecommunications
Connectivity is a 21st century expectation and imperative for people's livability, livelihood and social connection.
Clyde and Clyde North are under 50 km from Melbourne CBD and have intermittent unacceptable mobile coverage.

The recent Blackspot Program installation of a Vodafone tower at Casey Fields has made little difference for local people, either in very close proximity or in a broader 10 km range. It also highlights the problem of sharing arrangements with only certain providers.

The area is growing rapidly, yet businesses and families are unable to make a telephone call with any confidence. Calls drop out to emergency services, to customers, to family, to businesses, to schools, in telehealth appointments. This is not inconvenient, this is life threatening and dangerous.

The year 2020 saw a fundamental change to how we connect both through work and social settings. Connectivity will become even more important to the way we operate in the future. Accessibility, affordability and reliability will be non-negotiable.
It is simply unacceptable for residents and businesses to wait patiently for years for mobile towers, through a funded Program which by nature is selective.
We therefore ask the House to expedite works to provide reliable phone coverage to the areas of Clyde and Clyde North in outer Melbourne.

We also ask that tower construction is not based on the current competitive mobile blackspot grants process, where even those base stations nominated in March 2021 may not commence operation until 30 June 2022.
from 1269 citizens (Petition No. EN2412)
Remaining Relative Visa

The current eligibility requirements of the Remaining Relative Visa (Subclass 115) are unfair at best and racist at worst denying a group of Australians (citizens by conferral) the right to reunite and live alongside their parents and siblings unless that group is prepared to wait for years or pay a fortune. If every Aussie is entitled to a Fair Go, then every Aussie is entitled to having parents and siblings in his or her life without having to meet ludicrously unreasonable conditions such as the ones in the Remaining Relative Visa.

Not only could a Remaining Relative Visa take years before it is granted, but it also requires that neither applicants nor their partners have near relatives living outside Australia erecting almost insurmountable barriers for Australians by conferral to enjoy the same rights that, say, 2nd or 3rd generation Aussies enjoy - living with family: parents and siblings.

While it is certainly sensible for the Australian government to demand that citizens sponsoring family members demonstrate their ability to provide care and support to them, it is grossly inhumane to deny a group of Australian citizens and their immediate family members still living abroad, especially the ones who need rescuing, the right to be with each other merely because the remaining relative's partner still has a near relative living outside Australia.
We therefore ask the House to urgently change the eligibility requirements of the Remaining Relative Visa (Sublass 115) by omitting 'or your partner's' from the wording of eligibility.
from 75 citizens (Petition No. EN2414)
Charitable Organisations

The Australian Charities and Not For Profit Commission Act of 2012 is in breach of S116 of our constitution in that it requires a religious test to qualify for registration on the Charities Commission of Not for Profit list of entities.

Similarly the Australian Taxation Office laws regarding tax concessions for religious entities breaches S116 of our constitution because it relies on the Charities Commission act to determine who is a charitable organisation.
There are several other Charity laws that include the religious test and these too must be examined and have the religious test removed.

We therefore ask the House to remove religious organisations from the Australian Charities legislation and other charities legislation and remove them from ACNC list of charitable organisations and remove religious organisations from the Taxation laws regarding tax concessions.
from 5 citizens (Petition No. EN2415)
Aviation Industry

Millions of Australians have been affected by the cancellations of air travel. Cancelled flights, disrupt and deny the intended travel arrangements. The reason for the original travel is compromised, such as attending a wedding or visit sick relatives, and may no longer be relevant or appropriate. Affected travelers are offered credit vouchers, instead of a refund.

The corporate practices of Jetstar, is particularly aggressive and misleading. Victims are being coerced into receiving credit vouchers, so as to nullifying refund claims. Victims are being pressured in resolving complaints that contravene acceptable consumer protection. Victims of these practices by the Airline companies involved, are left thousands of dollars out of pocket.

Affected travelers are directed to an offshore call center, that has no authority to resolve complaints. They are left waiting online for up to an hour, only to be dismissed. The victims have to spend an unreasonable amount of time trying to get their complaint addressed, but the process causes immeasurable distress and inconvenience to them, their families and loved ones.

We therefore ask the House to pass measures for any air travel, which is cancelled by an airline for whatever reason, to be automatically refunded to the consumers affected, without delay and that the existing practice of offering vouchers for cancelled air travel be disallowed.
from 381 citizens (Petition No. EN2418)
Social Media

Following recent banning of posts and accounts of Donald Trump on Twitter, Facebook, Google and especially YouTube, governments need to rein in (Big Techs) power to influence. Their is no facet of life that Google, and its subsidiary YouTube are not controlling. YouTube has been deleting my posts/ comments for no reason what so ever, yet allow left wing political ads to swear, and knock the Australian Government.

We therefore ask the House to make it illegal for digital platforms to delete posts or comments that abide by the platforms conditions of service, and break no Australian Laws. It is a fundamental right to have freedom of speech, and a difference of opinion in a Democracy.
from 80 citizens (Petition No. EN2419)
Social Media

A Petition is circulating on a private platform stating ''for the third consecutive poll, the number of Australians reporting they'll refuse the covid vaccine is rising.'' It is true that social media feeds are flooded with conspiracy theories and reliable information about covid-19 and the questions around the vaccine. But it is up to the people to decide what is reliable information and what is not. The circulating petition claims that ''only the tech giants know the full picture of how this misinformation is polluting our newsfeeds. But they won't share this information with health experts.'' There is no lawful requirement for social media companies to share social media posts with alleged medical experts, it is up to a person's local GP, to inform a person/patient about whether or not, a covid vaccine is right for them, and to educate their patient about covid where that person can make an informed decision, not a group of medical interlopers who spy on & police social media posts.

We therefore ask the House to consider not giving access to the ''Live List'' to Health Experts, giving access to the same birds eye view of trending covid related posts that Facebook or Youtube has. It may violate & interfere with implied rights to political communication and free speech, and gives them special access the rest of the public does not have, which is discriminatory, their interference will allegedly violate Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights as to interference.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN2421)
Workplace Relations

We are petitioning you on behalf of Australians living off the National Minimum Wage. The Fair Work Ombudsman specifies that as of 1 July 2020 the National Minimum Wage is $19.84 per hour. The Australian Bureau of Statistics 'Employee Earnings' specifies that as of August 2020 the median hourly earning in Australia was $36 per hour (or $71,136 gross annually for 38 hours work per week). But for someone earning the National Minimum Wage their gross annual pay for 38 hours work per week would be only $39,203.84.

We therefore ask the House to please take action to reduce poverty. We appreciate the Fair Work Ombudsman's regular reviews of the National Minimum Wage, however we are petitioning for it to be raised to $20 per hour. This would be a difference of only $0.16 per hour - $6.08 per week, which is $12.16 per fortnight, and $316.16 annually. To the Hon. Speaker of the House of Representatives and Members of the House of Representatives, we ask if sixteen cents is too much to help reduce poverty in Australia? We ask that if the House approves this petition, that it is put into effect in all Australian states and territories within two years of its approval. We thank you for taking the time to consider this petition and look forward to your response.
from 41 citizens (Petition No. EN2427)
JobKeeper Payment

As of May 2020, approximately 750,000 students were enrolled in ELICOS courses in Australia, a similar number to those enrolled in VET and higher education. ELICOS accounts for approximately 23% of GDP gained from international students. In addition to the immediate financial benefits, one must consider the long-term contribution to the economy. Students who start their Australian journey in an English language course often progress to VET courses or tertiary education. Many continue along the path to eventual permanent residency, but even those who return to their own country will have established strong and enduring ties to this country. At each step, they are putting money into the Australian economy. Australia has thus far navigated the coronavirus pandemic far more successfully than other major international student destinations such as the UK, the United States and Canada. We are thus poised to re-establish ourselves as the country of choice for overseas students. But where will they study? Who will teach them? Training centres are closing at an alarming rate and experienced teachers are being forced to search for employment in other sectors.

We therefore ask the House to continue Jobkeeper payments for those employed in the ELICOS sector beyond March 31st in order to keep schools open, keep teachers employed and help to ensure that the sector is ready and able to deliver excellent education to international students from day one. This represents a sound investment in Australia's future.
from 230 citizens (Petition No. EN2428)
PETITIONS

span.span: I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:

p.span: JobSeeker Payment
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 19 October 2020 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning JobSeeker and JobKeeper (Petition number EN1732). Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. I apologies for the delay in responding.

JobSeeker Payment provides income support to those looking for work or who temporarily cannot work or study because of an injury or sickness. It strikes a balance between supporting individuals while maintaining incentives for recipients to support themselves to the greatest extent possible. The social security system aims to support people back into the workforce, be targeted to those most in need and be fiscally sustainable to ensure a safety net reminds in place for future generations.

The Australian Government is committed to temporary, targeted and scalable support during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Coronavirus Supplement was introduced from 27 April 2020 to provide additional financial support to eligible income support recipients, such as JobSeeker Payment, during COVID-19. The amount of the Supplement has been adjusted to reflect gradually improving economic conditions. Until 24 September 2020 the rate was $500 per fortnight. From 25 September to 31 December 2020 the rate was $250 per fortnight. From 1 January to 31 March 2021 the rate is $150 per fortnight.

The JobKeeper Payment was designed to ensure eligible employees remain connected to their workforce. The scheme was always intended to be temporary to cushion the economic impact of COVID-19. As conditions improved, the employee reference date was changed from 1 March to 1 July 2020 and the payment was further targeted. The payment is scheduled to end on 28 March 2021.

As the economy moves to a recovery phase, the JobMaker Hiring Credit is a key part of the Government's JobMaker Plan. It will help young people access job opportunities and rebuild their connection to the labour force as the economy recovers. The JobMaker Hiring Credit incentivises businesses to take on additional employees that are young job seekers aged 16 to 35 years old.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COVID-19: Vitamin D
Dear Mr O'Dowd
I refer to your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning Petition number EN2048 for Vitamin D services. Please find information below in respect to each matter raised.

span.span: I. Introduce a government-subsidised national Vitamin D (and other critical nutrients) supplementation program.

p.span: The Australian Government is committed to providing all Australians access to safe, effective and affordable medicines. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) is the main mechanism through which the Government can subsidise the cost of medicines for the treatment of Australian patients. The Government subsidises a comprehensive range of medicines through the PBS, including over 5,200 branded products to treat a wide range of medical conditions.

The Government cannot list a new medicine on the PBS, or change the circumstances of an existing listing, unless recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). The PBAC is an independent, expert body, which advises the Government about PBS matters. When considering a medicine proposed for PBS listing, the PBAC uses a rigorous Health Technology Assessment methodology to evaluate applications and is required to consider the effectiveness and cost of the medicine, including by comparison with alternative treatments. The PBAC's consideration is generally initiated by the pharmaceutical company responsible for a medicine making an application for PBS listing. This is because the pharmaceutical company usually holds the scientific data and other information necessary to inform the PBAC's consideration.

Vitamin D supplements are over-the-counter medicines, available without a prescription. In general, pharmacy medicines that do not require a prescription are not listed on the PBS, as they are inexpensive and, after applying the pharmacy remuneration charges for dispensing, the cost of these products to the Government when accessed via the PBS is disproportionally inflated.

span.span: Re-introduce Medicare-funded pathology testing for Vitamin D and other critical nutrients.

p.span: Pathology testing for Vitamin D is currently subsidised by the Government under the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), which is part of the wider Medicare Benefits Scheme managed by my Department and administered by Services Australia. In the 2019-20 financial year, the Government provided $104 million in Medicare benefits and supported over 4 million services for Vitamin D testing.

MBS Items 66833, 66834, 66835 66836 and 66937 provide an MBS benefit for Vitamin D testing in individuals at risk of Vitamin D deficiency. The items were introduced in 2014, replacing the previous items that supported Vitamin D testing, to best ensure the item descriptors align with clinical guidelines.
Similarly, pathology testing for a range of other critical nutrients are also currently MBS subsidised. For example:
Vitamin Bl2 testing may be claimed under MBS items 66838 and 66839
Vitamins B1, B2, B3, B6 or C testing may be claimed under MBS items 66605 and 66606
Folate (also known as Vitamin B9) testing may be claimed under MBS items 66840
Copper, Manganese, Selenium, or Zinc testing may be claimed under MBS items 66819, 66820, 66821, and 66822.

span.span: Increase funding through the NHMRC (and other sources) for research in nutritional medicine with a particular emphasis on the future management of epidemic and pandemic outbreaks.

p.span: The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) is the Government's lead agency for funding health and medical research. NHMRC distributes grants through a range of schemes with specific aims, e.g. to invest in people with outstanding research achievement and promise, to support the most innovative research to solve complex problems, and to meet specific strategic objectives. Most NHMRC funding is awarded in response to investigator-initiated applications and is not directed by NHMRC to any specific disease, health or research topic. A small proportion of funding is directed to specific areas of unmet need, e.g. through Targeted Calls for Research (TCR) and other special initiatives. The primary criterion for all funding decisions is excellence. NHMRC relies on rigorous, competitive peer review that identifies the best science and most significant research.

From 2011-2020, NHMRC provided funding of over $1.2 billion for research related to nutritional diseases, including over $82 million for research into nutritional deficiencies and supplements. NHMRC provides support for research related to epidemic and pandemic preparedness through a number of grant schemes. In particular, the Australian Partnership for Preparedness Research on Infectious Disease Emergencies (APPRISE) Centre of Research Excellence was awarded a five-year NHMRC grant from 2016-2021 to build national research preparedness for major infectious disease outbreaks. In 2020, a further $2 million was awarded to APPRISE to undertake rapid research in direct response to the COVID-19 emergency.

Whilst it cannot commit to funding increases in these areas, the NHMRC continues to welcome research grant applications across the health and medical research spectrum. The NHMRC will also continue to consider and prioritise new TCR topic proposals from community and professional groups, as well as from states, territories and the Australian Government, in accordance with established processes. Further information on NHMRC grant schemes and processes can be found on NHMRC's website at: www.nhmrc.gov.au.

span.span: Encourage further education in nutritional medicine for Medical Practitioners, allied health professionals and the broader health workforce.

p.span: In relation to the request to encourage further education in nutritional medicine for medical practitioners, allied health professionals and the broader health workforce, responsibility for setting continuing professional development requirements for practitioners registered under the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency sits with the National Boards that govern the curriculum, education and training standards for each of the registered professions.

span.span: Improve community access.to evidence-based, safe nutritional medicines through the pharmacy sector.

p.span: The petition refers to the use of evidence-based nutritional medicines (such as Vitamins D, C and Zinc) to support an individual's immune health during the COVID-19 pandemic.

In Australia, nutritional medicines are regulated as therapeutic goods under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 (Act) by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA). The TGA is responsible for ensuring that therapeutic goods available for supply in Australia are safe and fit for their intended purpose. This is achieved through a risk-based system whereby medicines are broadly classified as either 'listed' (low-risk) or 'registered' (high-risk) based on the ingredients they contain and the therapeutic indications (claimed health benefits) they use. Medicines approved for supply are entered on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG) and can be identified by AUSTL or AUSTR identification numbers on the labels. The TGA is not involved in business decisions relating to the sale of products.

In Australia, medicines indicated to prevent or treat COVID-19 are regulated as prescription medicines, which must be prescribed by a GP. These registered medicines, which are generally higher risk and intended for serious conditions or diseases, undergo a full pre-market assessment to ensure they are safe, of high quality and effective for their intended use.

In contrast, complementary medicines, which include nutritional medicines, such as Vitamin D and other micronutrients, are generally regulated as lower-risk listed medicines, which are available for self-selection at pharmacies, supermarkets or health stores etc. Listed medicines are not able to be indicated for or refer to the treatment, prevention or control of serious diseases, such as COVID-19, and are not subject to a pre-market assessment.

Nutritional medicines and other medicines that are marketed as lower risk listed medicines can only contain pre-approved, low-risk ingredients and only make pre-approved low level indications that are supported by appropriate evidence. Although these medicines are not evaluated before being released on the Australian market, the supplier must legally certify at the time of market approval that they hold appropriate evidence to support the claims being made. If, during a post-market compliance review of any listed medicine in the market place, this certification is found to be false, then compliance action can be taken to correct any misleading information associated with the listed medicine or the product may be cancelled from the ARTG.

A new category of lower risk medicines that is also available for nutritional medicine products is assessed listed medicine (identified on the label with an AUSTL(A) identification number). This category of medicine is also available for self-selection at pharmacies, supermarkets or health stores etc; however, such products are able to carry higher level indications than those permitted for use in standard listed medicines. To ensure this category of medicine remains lower risk (than registered medicines) assessed listed medicines undergo a pre-market assessment of the evidence to support the efficacy of the proposed indications for the product. These products may claim on their label that the product has been 'TGA assessed'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Education
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 15 February 2021, regarding the response to petition EN2055 asking the Australian Government to consider making changes to remove compulsory English units.

The nationally agreed Foundation-Year 10 Australian Curriculum (the curriculum), endorsed by all Education Ministers, sets the expectations for what all Australian students should be taught, regardless of where they live or their background.
The aim of the English learning area within the curriculum is to ensure that students:

learn to listen to, read, view, speak, write, create and reflect on increasingly complex and sophisticated spoken, written and multimodal texts across a growing range of contexts with accuracy, fluency and purpose

appreciate, enjoy and use the English language in all its variations and develop a sense of its richness and power to evoke feelings, convey information, form ideas, facilitate interaction with others, entertain, persuade and argue
understand how Standard Australian English works in its spoken and written forms and in combination with non-linguistic forms of communication to create meaning
develop interest and skills in inquiring into the aesthetic aspects of texts and develop an informed appreciation of literature.
The English Curriculum maintains the focus on developing reading and literacy skills which help young people to acquire the knowledge and skills needed to allow them to fully participate in society.

It is important to note, that while the Australian Government plays a national leadership role in school education, State and Territory Governments and non-government education authorities and individual schools are responsible for the day-to-day delivery of education programs. They make decisions about the translation of the curriculum into the curriculum that is experienced by students, taking into account their context and community needs.

On 12 June 2020, all Education Ministers agreed to a Review of the Australian Curriculum. Ministers have tasked the Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority (ACARA) to refine, realign and declutter the content of the curriculum and refine and reduce the amount of content across all eight learning areas of the curriculum. Information on the review can be found at www.acara.edu.au/curriculum/curriculum-review.

Subject matter teacher professional associations, teacher unions, academics, principal and parent groups and other key stakeholder groups will be extensively engaged and consulted throughout the review process in a range of ways appropriate to each specific learning area.
ACARA will have one 10 week formal consultation period for feedback on proposed changes to the curriculum content. This consultation will commence on 29 April 2021.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education and Youth, Mr Tudge
Land Ownership
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2149 - stop all non-Australian citizens from being able to own any land or property within Australia. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Foreign investment drives economic growth, creates skilled jobs, improves access to overseas markets and enhances productivity. Without foreign investment, production, employment and income would all be lower.

At the same time, the Australian Government recognises community concerns around foreign ownership of certain Australian assets including residential real estate. The foreign investment review framework allows the Government to consider these concerns when assessing Australia's national interest while ensuring Australia remains an attractive place to invest. If it is determined that a proposal is contrary to the national interest, it will not be approved, or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

In relation to residential land, under Australia's foreign investment review framework foreign persons generally need to apply for foreign investment approval before purchasing residential real estate in Australia. The Government's policy is to channel foreign investment into new dwellings, as this increases the total dwelling stock in which Australians can live, creates additional jobs in the construction industry and supports economic growth.

Consistent with this aim, applications to purchase new dwellings are usually approved without conditions and applications to purchase vacant land are normally approved subject to construction being completed within four years (to prevent land banking).

Non-resident foreign persons are generally prohibited from purchasing established dwellings in Australia. However, reflecting the fact that foreign persons who are temporary residents need a place to live during their time in Australia, temporary residents can apply to purchase one established dwelling to use as a residence while they live in Australia. The purchase of an established dwelling in these circumstances would normally be conditional on the foreign person selling the property when they leave Australia. Temporary residents cannot acquire established dwellings to rent out or for use as a holiday home.

In relation to agricultural land, this is a sector in which the Government has acted to improve scrutiny and transparency around foreign ownership. The Government has clarified that foreign investors can only acquire agricultural land where there has been an open and transparent sale process - thereby ensuring Australian bidders have equal opportunity to participate in a given sale process.

You may be interested to know that comprehensive reforms to the foreign investment review framework came into effect of 1 January 2021. These reforms update the framework in three broad ways: they address national security risks; strengthen the existing system, particularly as it relates to compliance by foreign investors; and streamline investment in non-sensitive businesses.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Tobacco Taxation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2166 - request to reduce the tax on tobacco products. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Australian Government discourages the use of all tobacco products as there is no form of tobacco use which has benign health effects for consumers. Despite the recent decline in the incidence of smoking, it remains a leading cause of preventable death and disability in Australia, with smoking estimated to have killed almost 21,000 Australians in 2015.

The World Health Organisation identifies price increases through taxation as one of the most effective ways governments can reduce tobacco consumption. Successive Australian governments have made significant efforts in recent years to reduce tobacco consumption through staged increases in tobacco excise and a swap to wage indexation.

The taxation of tobacco products, apart from discouraging smoking, helps to pay for support for people who wish to quit smoking, essential services such as the delivery of health services and other areas of spending that benefit the whole Australian community.

The Government supports a range of services designed to help people quit, including the My QuitBuddy and Quit for You - Quit for Two mobile apps, and confidential support and advice through the Quitline (13 78 48). In addition, certain smoking cessation products are subsidised on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Further information about quitting smoking can be found on the Department of Health website at: www.health.gov.au/health-topics/smoking-and-tobacco/how-to-quit-smoking.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Diabetes
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning petition EN2168 - request to extend eligibility criteria for the Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) Initiative.

The Australian Government is aware of the significant impact diabetes has on people with diabetes and their families, and is committed to working towards the broad prevention of the disease in the Australian community.
The CGM Initiative began in 2017, and provides fully subsidised CGM products to eligible people. Since that time, the eligibility criteria have been expanded to allow more people to benefit.
On 2 February 2020, I announced changes to the eligibility criteria that will result in more than 20,000 additional people having free access to CGM products.

The changes allow all people with type 1 diabetes aged 21 years or older who have concessional status to access CGM products, removing the requirement for these people to be assessed as having 'high clinical need'. This change will increase the total number of people eligible for CGM products to over 58,000.
The Government now provides fully subsidised CGM products to:
children and young people, under 21 years of age, with type 1 diabetes
children and young people with conditions very similar to type 1 diabetes, such as cystic fibrosis related diabetes and neonatal diabetes, who require insulin
women with type 1 diabetes who are planning for pregnancy, pregnant or immediately post-pregnancy
people with type 1 diabetes aged 21 years or older who have concessional status.

Also, on 1 March 2020, the Freestyle Libre Flash Glucose Monitoring system was added to the range of products subsidised under the CGM Initiative. This increases options for eligible people with diabetes in managing their condition.
Any decision to further expand the CGM Initiative would need to be considered against competing priorities in the Health Budget.

A review of products subsidised under the CGM Initiative has recently commenced. The review is being conducted to ensure that all CGM products are assessed on a consistent and transparent basis, and will inform future decision-making in relation to the CGM Initiative including consideration of new products. The review is expected to be completed in mid-2021.

The Government provides considerable additional support to people with diabetes, including those people not eligible for the CGM Initiative. The Government subsidises essential medicines, like insulin, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and diabetes-related products through the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS).

The NDSS provides subsidised syringes and needles, blood glucose test strips, urine ketone test strips and insulin pump consumables to people with diabetes. It also provides educational and information services to assist in the best use of products and self-management of diabetes.
More information about the CGM Initiative is available on the NDSS website at: www.ndss.com.au/cgm.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Heath and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Business
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2184 relating to the Boosting Cash Flow for Employers measure. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

To be eligible for support from the Boosting Cash Flow for Employers measure, entities are required to have (on or before 12 March 2020) an Australian Business Number and evidence of an active business. The evidence can be either of assessable income in a 2018-19 tax return, or of supplies, such as sales, that occurred in a tax period applying to the entity that started after 1 July 2018 and ended before 12 March 2020. Typically, entities have provided evidence of supplies by lodging activity statements in line with standard reporting procedures.

I appreciate that as a result of the design of the measure not every business will be eligible, however, this requirement is an important integrity feature to prevent schemes designed to artificially access support from this measure. By using existing systems with the Australian Taxation Office, this measure has been able to provide timely support without new and additional processes on businesses.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Fuel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2193 relating to petrol prices. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Australian Government has directed the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to continue to monitor fuel prices in Australia. In its recent reports, the ACCC has found that the key factors affecting fuel prices remain international crude oil and exchange rates. For example, increases in international oil prices typically lead to increases in domestic petrol prices. Its most recent report can be found at: www.accc.gov.au/media-release/australian-petrol-prices-higher-but-still-below-pre-pandemic-levels.

Petition EN2193 appears to raise concerns about petrol price cycles. Petrol price cycles occur when prices oscillate between high and low points. Typically, prices steadily fall for a period followed by a sharp increase. The ACCC's website provides information on petrol prices cycles and gives buying tips: www.accc.gov.au/consumers/petrol-diesel-lpg/petrol-price-cycles#petrol-price-cycles-in-capital-cities.

The level of competition between fuel retailers is also very important. To help drive competition, the ACCC recommends that consumers take advantage of fuel price websites and mobile applications that allow them to select the best time to purchase fuel, as well as the cheapest location
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Parliamentarians' Superannuation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 15 February 2021 seeking a response to petition number EN2195 concerning parliamentarians' superannuation contribution rate.

Parliamentarians who joined the Parliament on or after 9 October 2004 are covered by superannuation arrangements under the Parliamentary Superannuation Act 2004 (the Act). As provided under the Act, parliamentarians are members of fully funded accumulation schemes and are entitled to the superannuation employer contribution rate of 15.4%. Parliamentarians who joined prior to this time are entitled to a defined benefit pension on retirement.

The level of parliamentary superannuation employer contributions needs to be considered in the context of the total remuneration package for parliamentarians. The independent Remuneration Tribunal determines the remuneration of parliamentarians, and can have regard to a range of factors, including superannuation, in reaching its determinations.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Finance, Senator Birmingham
Medicare
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning petition EN2200. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

On 8 July 2020 I responded to petition EN1587, which I have attached. I note that petition EN2200 raises the same concerns and has the same principal petitioner as petition EN1587, and therefore I refer you to my response to petition EN1587.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1587 - Medicare Levy. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

I understand the petitioner's concerns that all Australians should pay their fair share of tax and Medicare levy. In Australia, a resident's income tax liability - for most taxes and for Medicare levy - is based on taxable income, after deductions are taken into account.

A basic principle of the Medicare levy is that it applies to an individual's taxable income from all sources. The fact that taxpayers are required to pay the Medicare levy on taxable Government assistance payments they receive—just as taxpayers are required to pay the Medicare levy on any wage and salary income—is consistent with this basic principle.

However, low-income earners are not liable for the Medicare levy. This is consistent with the progressive nature of income tax, which means those on lower taxable incomes pay less tax. The Medicare levy low-income thresholds ensure that households do not pay Medicare levy if their taxable income is below a certain level, and the amount payable is phased-in over a certain income range. These arrangements ensure that the liability of people to pay the Medicare levy reflects their financial capacity to contribute to the total cost of national health care, and is not merely a payment for service.
The Government considers the current Medicare levy settings to be appropriate.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Fuel Excise
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2208 - request to remove petrol and diesel excise indexation. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

Fuel excise is paid on all fuel manufactured in Australia or imported into Australia for home consumption. The Australian Government uses revenue from excise, including fuel taxes, to fund essential services that all Australians receive benefits from, such as the delivery of social services, defence and security, road funding and numerous other areas of spending of benefit to the whole community.

The Government passed legislation to reintroduce the indexation of fuel excise to inflation. From August 2014, fuel excise increases twice a year, in February and August, in line with movements in the Consumer Price Index (CPI). These are the same arrangements that were in place before indexation was frozen in 2001. Alcohol and tobacco excise, like fuel excise, are also indexed twice a year, in line with the CPI.

Implementing this important structural fiscal reform contributes significantly to the Government's efforts to build a stronger, more prosperous economy. Every additional dollar raised by the increase in fuel excise from indexation is linked by law to the funding of roads. While the impact on individual households is modest, this measure provides a predictable and stable source of revenue, which will help the Government boost its investment in road infrastructure.

The Government provides fuel tax credits for fuels consumed by a subset of fuel end-users. These are currently equal to 100 per cent of the fuel excise amount charged on the fuel consumed by these eligible users. To see if users are eligible for fuel tax credits, please refer to: www.ato.gov.au/Business/Fuel-schemes/Fuel-tax-credits---business/.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COVID-19: Economy
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1414 with respect to support for the event industry. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter. Please accept my sincere apologies for being slow to respond. I have received a large number of emails and requests for information and have not been able to respond as quickly as I would like.

The Australian Government is aware that businesses in the event industry were among the first affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, through the closure of borders and domestic restrictions to keep Australians safe. In recognition that events providers are operating in an exceptional set of circumstances due to COVID-19, the Government announced on 11 September 2020, a $50 million Business Events Grants Program to support businesses in the sector. On 11 March 2021, the Government announced that it would extend the program for three months and make changes to the program guidelines so that more businesses are eligible to benefit.

The extended Business Events Grants Program will provide grants of between $5,000 and $250,000 to cover up to 50 per cent of costs incurred in participating eligible business events. Further information about the program can be found on Austrade's website here:
www.austrade.gov.au/Australian/Tourism/Tourism-and-business/Grants/business-events-exhibitor-grants-program.

The Government also recently announced that it will expand and extend its existing SME Guarantee Scheme to support the economic recovery, and to provide continued assistance to firms currently on JobKeeper. The SME Recovery Loan Scheme will benefit from an increased government guarantee, allowing lenders to offer a 24 month repayment holiday, longer loan terms, larger loan sizes and the ability for borrowers to refinance existing debt.

These programs are in addition to the Government's significant economic support for businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic. JobKeeper was a key feature of the Government's response, with around $86 billion in JobKeeper payments made over the two phases of the program to date. In addition, the Boosting Cash Flow for Employers measure has provided around $35 billion in cash flow support to eligible businesses.

More generally, businesses in the events industry will benefit from the economy recovery that is now well underway. The strength of the domestic economic recovery over the second half of 2020 and in early 2021 has consistently exceeded the expectations of most economic forecasters. In particular, the labour market has recovered quickly, with the unemployment rate falling and workforce participation returning to around record high levels. The vaccine roll-out is also gathering pace, supporting domestic borders to remain open and providing greater certainty for people to travel for both business and leisure purposes. Nevertheless, the Government is mindful that some parts of the economy, such as the events sector, remain impacted by ongoing health measures and border closures and will continue to monitor economic conditions closely to see if further action is required.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COVID-19
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN1523 concerning the Australia-China relationship. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The China relationship has never been more important nor more complex for Australia. The Government is committed to the careful management of the relationship to achieve a partnership which advances our security and economic interests without compromising our national values.

The Government has made clear to China our willingness to address our differences through dialogue. We believe it is in all our interests to work sensibly through the issues and address them individually and on their merits.

At the same time, the Government is working to protect our exporters and the jobs they support. We continue to negotiate new free trade agreements, including with the European Union and the United Kingdom. These build on the existing agreements the Government has secured including those with Japan and South Korea and the recently signed Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership.
Thank you again for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment, Mr Tehan
COVID-19: International Travel

span.span: Thank you for your letter of 19 October 2020 to the Hon Peter Dutton MP, Minister for Home Affairs, regarding a petition on international travel and quarantine restrictions. Your letter was forwarded to me on 1 February 2021 as I am the Minister responsible for the matters raised.

Quarantine arrangements for international passenger arrivals remain one of the most effective measures to protect against the spread of COVID-19 in the Australian community. The operational and cost arrangements for quarantine facilities are a matter for the individual state and territory jurisdictions.

s major international airports were put in place by the Australian Government in July 2020, following urgent requests from the States to assist with the management of international passenger arrivals given major pressures on their quarantine capacity. These caps were agreed by National Cabinet and currently limit the national total number of international passenger arrivals to Australia.

p.span: The Government has also put in place an arrangement with the Northern Territory Government to provide significant additional capacity at the Howard Springs quarantine facility near Darwin, which is enabling the operation of a number of Government facilitated flights helping vulnerable Australians return, the first of which arrived on 23 October 2020. The Government has also announced an additional 20 facilitated commercial flights over the period to 31 March 2021.

International air passenger arrival caps are subject to ongoing review by National Cabinet, which is committed to supporting additional capacity on scheduled international commercial services for returning Australians where quarantine capacity allows and the public health advice is that it is safe to do so.

Australians who remain overseas are encouraged to subscribe to the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFAT) website at www.smartraveller.gov.au for the latest advice and follow the social media account of their closest embassy, consulate or high commission for regular updates. Should they require urgent assistance while overseas, they can also contact the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 from anywhere in the world. Australians overseas in need of consular assistance can also register with DFAT via covid19.dfat.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to the Government's attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack
Australian Securities Exchange
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your personal representation, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition (ENI758) Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) investigation into the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX). Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

As a holder of an Australian Market License (AML), the ASX is subject to statutory obligations to ensure its market is fair, orderly, and transparent. It must also have adequate arrangements for handling conflicts between commercial interests and its statutory obligations, as well as also having adequate arrangements to monitor and enforce its operating rules.

ASIC currently regulates the ASX as the holder of an AML under Part 7.2 of the Corporations Act. The ASX is responsible for the management of the listing rules, subject to its obligations under Part 7.2. ASIC can choose to investigate alleged breaches of the Corporations Act, including of the AML obligations under Part 7.2.

While the Minister is empowered to give ASIC directions in relation to its policies and priorities, the Minister cannot give directions about particular cases. If a person believes the ASX has contravened its obligations under Part 7.2, including the obligations outlined above, they can report the alleged breach to ASIC at: www.asic.gov.au/about-asic/contact-us/how-to-complain/.

The Council of Financial Regulators (CFR) has published the Regulatory Expectations for Conduct in Operating Cash Equity Clearing and Settlement Services in Australia (Regulatory Expectations) which outlines the CFR agencies' expectations of ASX as the monopoly provider of cash equity clearing and settlement services in Australia. The Regulatory Expectations are available at:
www.cfr.gov.au/publications/policy-statements-and-other-reports/2016/regulatory-expectations-policy-statement/.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and the Digital Economy, Senator Hume
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 9 November 2020 to the Hon Peter Dutton MP, Minister for Home Affairs, regarding a petition on lifting the cap on international passenger arrivals. As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your letter was forwarded to me for consideration.

Quarantine arrangements for international passenger arrivals remain one of the most effective measures to protect against the spread of COVID-19 in the Australian community. The operational and cost arrangements for quarantine facilities are a matter for the individual state and territory jurisdictions.

Passenger arrival caps at Australia's major international airports were put in place by the Australian Government in July 2020, following urgent requests from the States to assist with the management of international passenger arrivals given major pressures on their quarantine capacity. These caps were agreed by National Cabinet and currently limit the national total number of international passenger arrivals to Australia.

The Government has also put in place an arrangement with the Northern Territory Government to provide significant additional capacity at the Howard Springs quarantine facility near Darwin, which is enabling the operation of a number of Government facilitated flights helping vulnerable Australians return, the first of which arrived on 23 October 2020. The Government has also announced an additional 20 facilitated commercial flights over the period to 31 March 2021.

International air passenger arrival caps are subject to ongoing review by National Cabinet, which is committed to supporting additional capacity on scheduled international commercial services for returning Australians where quarantine capacity allows and the public health advice is that it is safe to do so.

Australians who remain overseas are encouraged to subscribe to the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFAT) website at www.smartraveller.gov.au for the latest advice and follow the social media account of their closest embassy, consulate or high commission for regular updates. Should they require urgent assistance while overseas, they can also contact the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 from anywhere in the world. Australians overseas in need of consular assistance can also register with DFAT via covidl9.dfat.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to the Government's attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack
Parliament
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 30 November 2020 to Senator the Hon Zed Seselja, the former Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities, and Electoral Matters. I am responding as the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters.

I note that petition EN2011 requests that the House stop any elected Member of Parliament of any political party to move/join another party or be independent without a by-election at their own expense.

On 10 December 2020, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM) tabled its report from the inquiry into the conduct of the 2019 Federal Election. In relation to by-elections and a sitting Member of Parliament (MP) resigning or leaving a party, the JSCEM recommended the Government consider further deliberations by JSCEM on:
the viability of replacing by-elections for the House of Representatives with alternative methods of selecting the replacement MP; and
the viability and ramifications of determining a seat to be declared vacant when the sitting MP resigns from or leaves the Party under which they were elected.
The Government is considering the JSCEM report recommendations and will respond in due course.
Thank you for bringing the matter referred to in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton

subdebateinfo.title: Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code

p.span: Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 3 December 2020 concerning petition number EN2026 outlining your support to amend the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (Code) to allow companion animals in non-food preparation areas of food premises.

In 2012, Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) examined the risk of companion dogs in outdoor dining areas under Proposal P1018 Companion Dogs in Outdoor Dining Areas. This proposal did not assess the presence of companion dogs or other animals inside food premises in non-food preparation areas. In August 2012, FSANZ approved the proposal and amended the Code to allow companion dogs in outdoor dining areas.

The Code permits assistance animals, such as guide dogs, to be present in dining, drinking or other areas of food premises used by customers. Although these animals may pose a risk to food safety, this risk is reduced because assistance animals are trained to follow a set of standard behaviour in public areas. Companion dogs that are not trained to this level may present a higher food safety risk.
If you wish FSANZ to make a change to the Code you need to submit a formal application to FSANZ. All applications undergo public consultation and a structured assessment process.
Further information on changing the Code can be found at: www.foodstandards.gov.au using the search term 'Changing the Code'.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Senior Australians and Aged Care Services and Minister for Sport, Mr Colbeck
Members of Parliament: Conduct
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021, requesting a response to petition EN2030, which asks the House to replace swivel chairs with fixed chairs that face the other side of the House. The reason given for the request is to make it difficult for the Prime Minister to turn away from debate.

In the House, Members are allocated seats and are expected to address the House from their own places. The Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition are allocated the seat on either side of the Table at the centre of the Chamber and speak from the despatch boxes at the Table.

There is a convention that a Minister should be present in the Chamber at all times, and in practice Governments maintain a roster of 'duty Ministers' who are not only in charge of items of government business but can react with authority on behalf of the Government to any unexpected development. When other matters are before the House—for example, during private Members' business, or adjournment or grievance debates—it is expected that a government representative will be available to take note of or respond to matters raised.

Duty Ministers sit at the Table in the Prime Minister's seat. Similarly, it is customary for the Opposition to maintain a roster of frontbenchers to sit at the Table, in the seat allocated to the Leader of the Opposition.

At the Table, swivel chairs are very practical. They make it easier for the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition or the Members on duty, to rise to speak from the despatch boxes on items of business or raise points of order. Their mobility also facilitates the changeover between duty Ministers and the Prime Minister or shadow ministers and the Leader of the Opposition.

The chairs themselves have an identical design to those in the committee rooms of Parliament House. The architects nominated these chairs, which are off-the-shelf items with custom finishes, for use in the committee rooms because of their design characteristics. They were selected for the Chamber in line with the precept of setting a unified design character within the building by using as few different furniture designs as possible.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention and I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Smith
Australian Republic
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding petition number EN2031, which asks that the House of Representatives call a referendum to create an Australian republic. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

A move to a republic, with an Australian Head of State, would require a change to the Australian Constitution through a constitutional referendum. The process for altering the Australian Constitution is set out in section 128 of the Constitution.

The Prime Minister has expressed his support for current constitutional arrangements. As you may be aware, any proposal to amend the Australian Constitution needs widespread community support to succeed. I add that, contrary to the suggestion in the petition, under the current constitutional arrangements, Australia is a sovereign, independent and federal nation.
The Commonwealth Government respects the right of all Australians to continue to express their views on these matters.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the attention of the Prime Minister.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton
Climate Change
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 regarding Petition Number EN2033 on Australia's commitments to the United Nations (UN) and Paris Agreement.

Australia's national interests, security and prosperity are served by a stable international order based on pragmatic and principled international cooperation among sovereign states. COVID-19 has demonstrated that the international order, underpinned by the agencies and bodies of the United Nations, is vital to address and coordinate a global response to a global challenge.

Australia's international engagement is guided by our national interests, including both our bilateral and multilateral engagement. The 2020 audit of Australia's engagement with the United Nations affirmed that multilateral institutions create rules that are vital to Australia's security, interests, values and prosperity. These institutions regulate international cooperation in key sectors including civil aviation, maritime transport, intellectual property, telecommunications and agriculture, among others, and promote universal values, such as human rights.

Climate change requires a global solution , with countries acting together to reduce emissions. Australia is committed to the Paris Agreement, the central international agreement on climate change which seeks to limit global warming. The Paris Agreement has near-universal support, with 191 parties having ratified or accepted the Agreement and having put forward emissions reductions commitments under the Agreement. Australia has welcomed the United States decision to re-join the Agreement in February 2021.

Australia is an active and constructive participant in the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, where we are working alongside other countries to pursue strong transparency requirements for all countries.

The Australian Government is committed to meeting its Paris Agreement target to reduce emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. Australia beat its 2020 target by 459 million tonnes and we are on track to meet and beat our 2030 Paris target.

In the year to September 2020, emissions were 510.1 million tonnes - 4.4 per cent or 23.3 million tonnes lower than in 2019. This is the lowest level since 1995. Australia's emissions are now 19.0 per cent below 2005 levels, which is the baseline year for our 2030 Paris Agreement target.

The Government is taking real and meaningful action to reduce emissions, with more than $5.6 billion committed to new emissions reduction measures through the last two federal Budgets. Australia's Technology Investment Roadmap will guide $18 billion of Government investment over the next 10 years to leverage $70 billion of new investment in Australia in low emissions technologies by 2030. Our plan will support 130,000 jobs by 2030 and avoid in the order of 250 million tonnes of emissions by 2040.

Investing in low emissions technologies will enable Australia's continued success in meeting and beating our emissions reduction targets. I assure the petitioners of Australia's continued commitment to influence and shape global institutions, while also safeguarding Australia's national interests.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Climate Change: Old Growth Forests
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 to the Minister for Agriculture, Drought and Emergency Management, the Hon David Littleproud MP, concerning Petition EN2059 - an end to Regional Forest Agreements (RFAs). Your correspondence was forwarded to me as I am the assistant minister responsible for the matter you raised.

The Australian Government considers that management of Australia's native forests should achieve a balance between the positive social and economic outcomes for regional communities provided by forestry, and environmental outcomes, such as protection for native species and their habitats. The government views RFAs as the most effective way of achieving this balance.

RFAs are long-term agreements between the Australian and the relevant state governments for the sustainable management and conservation of Australia's forests. Through the development of the RFAs the Commonwealth accredited each state's system of legislation, policies, codes, plans, agreements, management practices and the associated compliance regimes to deliver ecologically sustainable forest management.

Within RFA regions, forestry operations conducted in accordance with RFAs are exempt from the Commonwealth assessment and approval requirements of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act), except where operations are within World Heritage or Ramsar wetland sites. The inclusion of RFA provisions within the EPBC Act recognises that in each RFA region a comprehensive regional assessment was undertaken to address the environmental objectives of the EPBC Act.

A key outcome of the RFAs was the establishment of a Comprehensive, Adequate and Representative (CAR) reserve system. Since the RFAs were signed, the area of native forest in conservation reserves in RFA regions has almost doubled - from 5.4 million hectares to 10 million hectares in 2019. These areas have been reserved based on identification of environmental values such as old-growth forest and threatened species. Other areas were identified as potentially being available for harvesting. In these areas, state governments have responsibility for forestry operations and must ensure these are conducted in accordance with the principles of ecologically sustainable forest management.

Between 2017 and 2020 the Australian Government has delivered extended RFAs. To inform the extension of the RFAs, the Australian and relevant state governments completed a further assessment of forest-related environmental, social and economic values in the RFA regions.
The extended RFAs provide a modernised approach to forest management, with improvements including:
rolling 20-year extensions to the RFAs, implemented when both parties agree that performance has been satisfactory (with the exception of Victoria's RFAs, which have been extended to 2030)
more transparency around the forecasting of timber volumes available for the forestry industry
modernised content, including clear references to Matters of National Environmental Significance, climate change, adaptation and carbon issues
streamlined and strengthened review and reporting requirements
improved communication and consultation between the Commonwealth and the RFA states, including the requirement for an annual meeting between the parties to the Agreement.
More information on RFAs can be found at agriculture.gov.au/forestry/policies/rfa.
I have sent a copy of this letter to Minister Littleproud and the Minister for the Environment, the Hon Sussan Ley MP.
Thank you bringing this petition to the government's attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Forestry and Fisheries, Senator Duniam
COVID-19: Australians Overseas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition EN2074 concerning an exemption from Australia's travel restrictions for parents of pregnant women and women in post-partum period to travel to Australia. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you know, to protect Australians from the outbreak of COVID-19, the Australian Government has progressively announced travel restrictions that limit travel to Australia. Until further notice, there is a prohibition on all foreign nationals seeking to travel to Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories or have been granted an individual exemption by the Commissioner of the Australian Border Force, Mr Michael Outram APM, or authorised decision-makers.
The travel restrictions have been successful in slowing the spread of COVID-19 in Australia, and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC).

Whilst I acknowledge the concerns raised through Petition N2074, these restrictions are in place to protect Australians from the potential health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers.

The Commissioner's guidelines available to decision-makers and publicly available on the Department of Home Affairs' website notes that travel exemption requests for individuals seeking to visit a close family member who is seriously ill, where there is little support in Australia would generally meet the inward exemption requirements. However, inclusion of any additional exempt categories will be a process informed by the expert health advice of the AHPPC.
You will also no doubt be aware of the Government's priority to ensure all vulnerable Australians currently overseas are able to return to Australia as soon as possible.

Due to the limited quarantine capacity across all states and territories, and associated restrictions on international flight numbers, it is imperative that international travel into Australia is limited to journeys that are for exceptional circumstances only.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2074 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Dutton
COVID-19: Australians Overseas
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 16 February 2021 regarding a petition on international passenger arrival caps.

Passenger arrival caps at Australia's major international airports were put in place by the Australian Government in July 2020, following urgent requests from the States to assist with the management of international passenger arrivals given major pressures on their quarantine capacity. These caps were agreed by National Cabinet and currently limit the national total number of international passenger arrivals to Australia.

International air passenger arrival caps are subject to ongoing review by National Cabinet, which is committed to supporting additional capacity on scheduled international commercial services for returning Australians where quarantine capacity allows and the public health advice is that it is safe to do so.

The Government has also put in place an arrangement with the Northern Territory Government to provide significant additional capacity at the Howard Springs quarantine facility near Darwin, which is enabling the operation of a number of Government facilitated flights helping vulnerable Australians return, the first of which arrived on 23 October 2020. The Government has also announced an additional 20 facilitated commercial flights over the period to 31 March 2021.

Australians who remain overseas are encouraged to subscribe to the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFAT) website at www.smartraveller.gov.au for the latest advice and follow the social media account of their closest embassy, consulate or high commission for regular updates. Should they require urgent assistance while overseas, they can also contact the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 from anywhere in the world. Australians overseas in need of consular assistance can also register with DFAT via covid19.dfat.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, providing the petition EN2079 under Standing Order 209(a) and (b). As the Minister responsible for the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), I am providing a written response to this petition to be considered by the Standing Committee on Petitions (the Committee).

The NDIS does not discriminate against people with disability seeking to access the NDIS based on the type of disability a person may have. Access requirements are set out in the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 (NDIS Act), including age, residency and disability or early intervention requirements. For the purposes of meeting the disability or early intervention requirements, the presence of an underlying condition, illness or injury is irrelevant. Rather, a person will be eligible for the NDIS if their disability is, or is likely to be, permanent and significantly affects their ability to undertake activities of communication, social interaction, learning, mobility, self-care or self-management.

I note the petition raises a decision made by the National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) in respect to a particular person. It would be inappropriate for me to comment on that individual case, or the decision made by the NDIA in respect of other any individual. Rather, I encourage all persons to pursue their right to review, including external review, should they feel a decision made by the NDIA about them is wrong.
I trust this information is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Mr Robert
Social Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning Petition EN2080 - websites that collect user data should provide an option to delete all historic data held in a one-click solution.
The petition requests that individuals be given the right to delete data from online platforms such as Facebook, and raises concerns about the collection of personal information from children.

The Morrison Government is committed to keeping Australians, and particularly children, safe online. Australia has strong regulatory controls and support systems that mitigate risks and empower Australians to confidently take advantage of the benefits of the internet.

In March 2019, the Government committed to strengthen the Privacy Act 1988 (Privacy Act) by increasing penalties and enforcement measures, and introducing a binding code for social media and other platforms that trade in personal information online. The code will require platforms to cease using or disclosing an individual's personal information upon request, strengthen requirements to be transparent about data sharing, and introduce specific rules to protect the personal information of children and other vulnerable groups. The legislation will soon be released for public consultation
