Separately, in December 2019 in response to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's Digital Platforms Inquiry, the Government committed to a review of the Privacy Act. The review is considering whether the Privacy Act effectively protects personal information and provides a practical and proportionate framework for promoting good privacy practices.

In October 2020 the Attorney General's Department released an issues paper for the review, which included consideration of whether a 'right to erasure' should be introduced into the Privacy Act. Consultation on the issues paper closed 29 November 2020, but a further opportunity to comment will be available following the release of a discussion paper expected in the first half of 2021. Further information about the review is available on the Attorney General's Department website, ag.gov.au/integrity/consultations/review-privacy-act-1988.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Social Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 15 February 2021, concerning Petition EN2084 - calling for a Royal Commission into Social Media and introduction of new laws that protect freedom of speech.

The Australian Government is committed to promoting the rule of law and the rights and protections we enjoy as a democratic nation. Of these, our right to free speech and free expression is one of the most highly valued and fiercely protected. The ability of citizens to speak freely and openly is the hallmark of a robust democracy.

However, there has never been an absolute right to free speech in Australia. Free speech is balanced against other considerations, such as whether speech is threatening, offensive or defamatory. The Government's position is that measures to filter, block or 'take down' content on social media websites should be used to protect users from harm, such as by removing online abuse material; or to remove material relating to serious criminal activity, such as content that represents an incitement to violence, or is child exploitation or child sexual abuse material.

Major digital platforms sites, including Facebook, Twitter and YouTube, also have terms of use that govern how users and others interact with them. Social media platforms are private corporations and are well within their rights to enforce their own terms of use and policies, which users agree to by using their service. It is a decision for the company to determine whether an account or piece of content is in breach of a company's policies and how it will respond. However, the Government expects social media platforms to consistently enforce their standards - which includes taking down harmfully misleading or illegal content.

The petition raises particular concerns with censorship of political discussion, particularly in relation to the United States of America's (US) 2020 presidential election. Social media website providers have made statements that they have flagged or censored user-generated content when that content breaches the website's terms of use, including by spreading misinformation.

The Government supports actions by social media website providers to combat misinformation. Following the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's Digital Platforms Inquiry in 2019, the Government directed industry to develop and implement an industry code of conduct to address disinformation and misinformation on their services. The Digital Industry Group Inc. (DIGI) developed the voluntary Australian Code of Practice on Disinformation and Misinformation (Code) on behalf of the Australian digital industry and released the Code on 22 February 2021. The Code has been adopted by Twitter, Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Redbubble and TikTok, with other digital platforms also encouraged to sign up. Further information on the Code is available on the DIGI website, digi.org.au/disinformation-code/.
Thank you for bringing these concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Australian Consumer Law
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2101: Remove Australian Consumer Law (ACL) section 61(4). Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

As the petitioner has noted, professional services supplied by qualified architects and engineers do not receive consumer guarantee protection under section 61 of the ACL. In that section, there is otherwise a guarantee that services supplied to consumers will be fit for any particular purposes that consumers make known to the supplier. The same guarantee also provides that services will be of such a nature, quality, state or condition, that they might reasonably be expected to achieve a result the consumer makes known to the supplier (or another party with whom they negotiate to acquire the supplier's services).

Services supplied by qualified architects and engineers have had a longstanding exemption dating back to an equivalent provision in the former Trade Practice Act 1974. Parliament originally regarded these professionals as a special category because their relationship with consumers in developing designs and specifications are subject to implementation by third parties, such as builders, and that they should not be held responsible for the actions of those other parties.

A similar rationale was provided when the ACL replaced that Act, but several other factors were noted, including that removing the exemption might increase insurance costs; architects and engineers often experience difficulties ascertaining the wishes of consumers when contracted to provide services; and consumers are adequately protected by other sources of redress.

In relation to the latter, if architects or engineers do not render services with due care and skill, they will be in breach of the consumer guarantee at section 60 of the ACL. This guarantee has no equivalent exemption for architects or engineers because it is targeted toward the specific actions of suppliers and not of other intervening parties. Consumers can also pursue a common law action in negligence if an architect or engineer owes a duty of care to the consumer and has failed to meet the standard required by that duty.

There are no plans at this time to amend the ACL to remove the exemption. In this regard, I note that the ACL is jointly administered by the Commonwealth and each of the states and territories under the Intergovernmental Agreement for the Australian Consumer Law. As such any proposals would require approval by Australia's Consumer Ministers following regulatory impact assessment. Ministers have recently agreed on other high priority tasks, which can be found at: www.consumerlaw.gov.au/consumer-affairs-forum/communiques/meeting-12-0. However, I have asked my department to raise this matter with state and territory officials as a potential issue for exploration when future priorities are considered.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Australian Parliament House Petitions Website
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021, requesting a response to petition EN2102 relating to the e-petitions website for the House of Representatives. The petition asks the House to update the petitions facility on the Parliament of Australia website to pre-fill signing details of a person signed in to the site and to enhance the website to display which petitions have been signed.

The e-petitions system, officially introduced in 2016, enables members of the public to submit and sign petitions online and also shows the progress of petitions as they are presented, referred to Ministers and responded to.

Currently there is no option to sign in to the e-petitions system, which is separate from the 'My Parliament' system. That system allows people to sign in, lodge submissions, track inquiries and stay in touch with updates to content on the Parliament's website.

The e-petitions system was designed to enable petitioners to sign a petition easily, without needing to log on or sign in. There is no option for people to see which petitions they have previously signed. However, when a person signs an e-petition, the system uses the signatory's email address to conduct automatic checks to make sure they have not previously signed that petition.

The suggestions raised by the petitioner have been noted for consideration in future system updates. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention and I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Smith
COVID-19: Australians Overseas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition EN2115 concerning seeking to exempt work visa holders to travel to Australia. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you know, to protect Australians from the outbreak of COVID-19, the Australian Government has progressively announced travel restrictions that limit travel to Australia. Until further notice, there is a prohibition on all foreign nationals seeking to travel to Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories or have been granted an individual exemption by the Commissioner of the Australian Border Force, Mr Michael Outram APM, or authorised decision-makers.
The travel restrictions have been successful in slowing the spread of COVID-19 in Australia, and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC).

As you are aware, temporary visa holders are free to leave Australia at any time. However, temporary visa holders seeking to re-enter Australia will require an exemption from the travel restrictions before they travel, unless they are in an exempt category.

Temporary visa holders seeking to leave and then return to Australia, may apply for an inwards exemption before they leave. More information about applying for a pre-emptive inwards exemption is outlined in the Commissioner's guidelines issued to decision-makers and are publicly available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions.

Whilst I acknowledge the concerns raised through Petition EN2115, these restrictions are in place to protect Australians from the potential health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers. Inclusion of any additional exempt categories will be a process informed by the expert health advice of the AHPPC.

You will no doubt be aware that protecting the health of Australians and bringing Australians home, especially vulnerable Australians, remains the Government's priority. Due to the limited quarantine capacity across all states and territories, and associated restrictions on international flight numbers, it is imperative that international travel into Australia is limited to journeys that are for exceptional circumstances only.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2115 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Dutton
Parliament
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 15 February 2021, requesting a response to petition EN2141 relating to the removal of religious observances at the start of parliamentary proceedings.

The standing orders set out that prayers will be read at the beginning of sittings, with the exact form of words included in standing order 38. It is for the House itself to decide whether and how to amend standing orders. For the wording of standing order 38 to be changed or be removed, a majority of Members must agree.

The prayer read at the beginning of proceedings remains largely unchanged since it was adopted in 1901, other than when additional words were introduced in 1918 for the remainder of World War I. While standing orders have been reviewed and amended over the years, the House has not chosen to change the practice of commencing with prayers.

Ultimately, as you know, responsibility for the operations of the House rests with the Members themselves, and any changes to the standing orders can only be approved with the support of a majority of Members.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Smith
Graduate Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition EN2165 concerning extending all current Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visas (TGV) for an additional year.

The Australian Government recognises the contribution TGV holders make in Australia. While the TGV provides eligible graduates with the opportunity to gain practical experience in Australia following their studies, it is important to note that the TGV is a temporary visa and does not guarantee employment or a pathway to permanent residence.

There are a range of options for international graduates to remain in Australia through the skilled migration program, which is driven by Australia's labour market needs. Further information is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/what-we-do/skilled-migration-program.

The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted the international community and respective health systems and economies. The primary focus of the Government is on protecting the health of Australians, supporting businesses and jobs, and maintaining the provision of essential goods and services while combatting the pandemic. The wellbeing of Australians who have become unemployed due to COVID-19 is of particular concern to the Government.

The Government recognises the impact that COVID-19 has had on many temporary visa holders. While the Government is not considering a general extension to the period of stay for TGV holders, it has adopted a flexible approach in relation to visa conditions and made a number of changes to visa arrangements during COVID-19 to support the sector. The student visa measures announced on 20 July 2020, include relaxing the eligibility requirements for a TGV to allow graduates to apply for, and be granted, a TGV outside Australia if they are unable to return to Australia due to COVID-19; and allowing student visa holders to count online study undertaken outside Australia towards the Australian Study Requirement for a TGV. Information about these visa measures is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.

In addition, in October 2019, the Government announced changes to Australia's migration program to increase the number of people who choose to live, study and work in regional Australia. The changes to allow an additional period of post-study work for certain TGV holders to support regional Australia took effect on 20 January 2021. Further information can be found on the Department's website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/temporary-graduate-485/second-post-study-work.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2165 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Trade with China
Dear Chair

I refer to recent correspondence regarding Petition Number EN2170. The petition draws to the attention of the House, recent actions of China in placing trade penalties on Australian goods that the petitioners allege are a retaliation to actions taken by Australia in our national interest.

Australia is facing a number of trade issues in our relationship with China, some dating back over a number of years. We have consistently maintained that we are available to work through issues, and to do that as calmly and effectively as possible in a manner respectful of each other's sovereignty. We will use the mechanisms of the World Trade Organisation to try to resolve matters or challenge decisions where appropriate, but as they are long processes, and we would far rather they be resolved through dialogue.

Australia has a long-standing and important relationship with China, which has delivered benefits to both sides. We seek a mature partnership based on respect for Australia's sovereign interests, as we respect China's sovereign interests. We will always be consistent about Australia's national interests and will stand firm on principle.

Bilateral trade and investment have contributed to economic success in both our countries, and Chinese and Australian people are deeply connected at the community level. While we have some differences on important issues, these ought not to disrupt normal contacts, including diplomatic relations.

The Australian Government has been clear that we seek to engage constructively with China. We raise our differences directly with China and we deal with challenges on their individual merits, as we always have. In this respect, Embassies and diplomatic staff are essential to maintaining official channels of communications between governments. Difficult times make open channels of communications with counterparts even more important.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 on behalf of the signatories to Petition EN2190 concerning allegations of worker exploitation.

Australia's Immigration Program has played a key role in nation building. The Department of Home Affairs' mission is to protect Australia's border and manage the movement of people and goods across it. An important part of managing the Australian border is the Department's implementation of Australia's universal visa system, under which all non-citizens require a valid visa to come to Australia. This system focuses on the contribution a person can make to Australia, rather than their ethnicity, gender or religious beliefs. Australia's temporary visa program, for example, is designed to allow people from other countries to come to Australia for specific purposes that benefit Australia. These include a temporary activity or work, international relations, study or training, or to visit.

In response to the specific issues raised in the Petition; all workers in Australia have the same rights and protections at work, regardless of citizenship or visa status. Employers must comply with Australian workplace and immigration laws, including their obligation to pay the right pay rate for all time worked and to provide a safe workplace. This includes employers engaged in the Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme.

The Australian Government will not tolerate the exploitation of any worker in Australian workplaces - it offends our national values of fairness and it harms not only the employees involved, but also the businesses which do the right thing. It also has the potential to undermine our international reputation as a country of choice for migrant workers.
All workers have the right to feel safe in the workplace. Employers, businesses and agents can be subject to large fines and possible time in prison if caught exploiting workers.

It is a serious criminal offence for an employer to force an employee to work by threatening or deceiving them, restricting their freedom to leave, or forcing them to pay off an unexplained debt. This behaviour should be reported to the Australian Federal Police by phone on: 131 237 or by completing the online form at: https://www.afp.gov.au/contact-us.

Notwithstanding the Government's position, and existing protections available to migrant workers, in 2016, the Government established the Migrant Workers' Taskforce (the Taskforce) to undertake a review into the ongoing issue of migrant worker exploitation. The Taskforce released its final report in March 2019. It included 22 recommendations, all of which have been agreed, in principle.

Since this time, the Department has been working with other key agencies to implement the Taskforce recommendations through a range of initiatives to further combat the issue of migrant worker exploitation.

If the signatories to this Petition believe they are being, or have been, exploited or underpaid, they should report to the Fair Work Ombudsman on 13 13 94. The Department will generally not cancel a person's visa for breaching work conditions, as long as they have reported their circumstance appropriately, agree to comply with work conditions in the future and there are no other reasons for cancelling the visa.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2190 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Citizenship
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition EN2196 concerning eligibility for Australian permanent residence for migrants over 40 years of age.

Australia's Migration Program is designed to maximise the economic prosperity, national wellbeing and social benefits of immigration by focusing on attracting and selecting highly skilled, young migrants who are less likely to draw from government services such as health, education and aged care.

Their contribution helps to reduce the adverse effects of an ageing population, drives higher workforce participation rates, and supports the growth of productivity and Gross Domestic Product, delivering positive flow-on effects for living standards to all Australians.

Age requirements for skilled visas generally seek to ensure prospective skilled migrants' potential contributions to the Australian economy are maximised, considering their contribution to the labour market, the broader economy and community.

Australia's strength and prosperity is linked to the economic and social contributions of successive generations of migrants and Australia's migration policies aim to enhance Australia's competitiveness, future economic capacity and social cohesion.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2196 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Asylum Seekers
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition EN2197 concerning Partner visa applicants whose sponsor entered Australia as an illegal maritime arrival (IMA).

Australia's migration, refugee and humanitarian programs are designed to achieve a range of economic and social outcomes. Having strong and effective border protection and immigration policies are integral to the successful implementation of these programs.

As you may be aware, under the Migration Act 1958, the Minister has the power to outline the order for considering and prioritising of visa applications. In doing so, the Minister takes account of the resources available, the Australian Government's policy intentions, the need to give priority to certain applications and the size and composition of the Migration Program.

The Government acknowledges the dangerous conditions many people experience around the world and remains committed to helping genuine refugees. Notwithstanding this, it is important to have measures in place to discourage people from risking their lives on a dangerous boat journey.

The Ministerial Direction No 80 (the Direction), which outlines the order for considering and disposing of family visa applications, forms part of the Government's overall efforts to combat people smuggling and will help sustain public confidence in the fairness of the family migration.

The Direction provides that the least priority for processing consideration would be applied to family visa applications in which the applicant's sponsor is a person who entered Australia as an IMA and holds a permanent visa. This means a person who enters Australia illegally by boat cannot gain an unfair advantage over those who arrive lawfully.

Nevertheless, the Direction enables a delegate to depart from the order of considering applications if they are satisfied that the application involves special circumstances of a compassionate nature, and there are compelling reasons to depart from that order. The Direction does not apply to former IMA sponsors who have acquired Australian citizenship or holders of protection visas who are not IMAs.

Furthermore, the Government has increased the number of places available to Family visa categories in the program year 2020-21, with 72,300 places allocated to Partner visas. This is an increase of 32,501 places from the 2019-20 planning level of 39,799 places and is expected to contribute to faster Partner visa processing timeframes.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2197 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Sport
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning Petition EN2202 in relation to the participation of transgender athletes in women's sport.
The Australian Government acknowledges the presentation of Petition EN2202 in the House of Representatives as well as the four signatories to the Petition.

The Government is committed to ensuring every person involved in sport is treated with respect and dignity and is protected from discrimination, harassment and abuse. It is important that sport is safe, fair and inclusive for all in order to ensure every Australian can enjoy the benefits of participating in sport. We want to see as many people playing sport as possible in Australia, as it promotes good physical and mental health and builds a sense of community.

The Government is a proud supporter of women's sport, funding a range of programs and initiatives to bolster the participation of women and girls and augment the increased coverage and investment women's sport has enjoyed in recent years. This includes support to ensure safety is embedded in the culture of Australian sporting organisations for every participant, is reflected in their policies and procedures and understood and practiced at all levels.

The Government recognises the role of National Sporting Organisations (NSO) as the governing bodies of their respective sports in Australia. NSOs are largely responsible for overseeing the network of organisations in their sport which run competitions and implement programs for their participants. This responsibility includes determining the eligibility of participants consistent with relevant federal and state laws.
Importantly, the Government expects that NSOs and professional leagues ensure the integrity of women's sport and sporting competitions is maintained.

At a Federal level, sporting organisations are also expected to comply with the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (Act) concerning the eligibility of participants, including transgender athletes. The Act notes circumstances where discrimination on the basis of sex or gender identity is allowed, including where 'any competitive sporting activity in which the strength, stamina or physique of competitors is relevant'.

In response to requests from a range of NSOs, a set of guidelines titled The Inclusion of Transgender and Gender Diverse People in Sport 2019 (Guidelines) were developed. The Guidelines were developed by the Australian Human Rights Commission in partnership with Sport Australia and the Coalition of Major Professional and Participation Sports. The Guidelines provide information on the Act and practical guidance on how sporting organisations can promote the inclusion of transgender and gender diverse people without disadvantaging females or compromising on the health and safety of participants. It is not mandatory for sporting organisations to follow or adopt the Guidelines. It is a matter for NSOs to consider and, if necessary, develop and oversee their own inclusion policies.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Sport, Mr Colbeck
Members of Parliament: Religious Affiliation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter dated 15 February 2021, requesting a response to petition EN2215, which asks the House to create a list of Pentecostal Christian Members of Parliament.

Under section 116 of the Constitution, no religious test is required as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth. As there is no requirement for Members to state any religious beliefs that they hold on taking office, it is not possible, or indeed appropriate, for the House to create a list of Members adhering to any particular faith.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention and I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Smith
Overseas Students
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 enclosing Petition EN2217 concerning seeking exemptions to international students to enter Australia. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you know, to protect Australians from the outbreak of COVID-19, the Australian Government has progressively announced travel restrictions that limit travel to Australia. Until further notice, there is a prohibition on all foreign nationals seeking to travel to Australia, unless they fall within certain exempt categories or have been granted an individual exemption by the Commissioner of the Australian Border Force, Mr Michael Outram APM, or authorised decision-makers.
The travel restrictions have been successful in slowing the spread of COVID-19 in Australia, and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.
As you are aware, the Commissioner or authorised decision-makers may grant an individual exemption for the following categories of international students:

those who are in their final two years of study of a medical, dental, nursing or Allied Health Profession university degree, where they have evidence of a confirmed placement in an Australian hospital or medical practice which commences within the next two months; and

those completing year 11 and 12, with endorsement from the federal Department of Education, Skills and Employment and support from the relevant Australian state or territory government health authority and education department.

Additionally, the Commissioner will personally consider travel exemption requests for people who are enrolled in an Australian education institution as a PhD research student, regardless of the visa type held.
International students are an important part of the Australian community, and we look forward to welcoming them back to our classrooms, campuses and communities, when conditions allow.
Protecting the health of Australians and bringing Australians home, especially vulnerable Australians, remains the Government's priority.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2217 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Dutton
Income Tax
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN2223 regarding the sending of personal tax statements to MyGov. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

At present, I understand that income statements are not sent to MyGov. Rather, when individuals create a MyGov account, they access their income statement, which has been compiled using information sent to the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) by their employer during the year through Single Touch Payroll (STP). If a taxpayer doesn't have a MyGov account, I understand that they are able to call the ATO on 13 26 61 to get a copy of their income statement.

Most employers are required to report through STP, which reduces their overall reporting obligations. STP reporting also provides benefits to individuals, such as providing up-to-date visibility of their tax and superannuation information and the pre-filling of income details into their tax return, which reduces the time it takes to lodge each year.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 March 2021, regarding your concerns about the National Disability Insurance Agency's (NDIA) delivery of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS).

The NDIS planning process involves the facilitation of a participant-led discussion to gain a picture of the participant's goals, aspirations, current life circumstances and supports. It necessitates a person-centred approach, recognising it is the start of a lifelong relationship between a participant and the NDIA. In assessing the needs of NDIS participants, the NDIA endeavours to work in partnership with the participant.

When identifying the types and amount of reasonable and necessary supports to provide, NDIA planners will review all information provided at the time of planning and make decisions based on the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 (NDIS Act), the rules made under the NDIS Act, and any relevant operational guidelines. The NDIA encourages participants to provide documentation, such as reports from allied health professionals, to assist the NDIA planner determine their required supports according to the NDIS Act.

The Australian Government is on track to deliver the most substantial package of reforms to the NDIS since its establishment, while at the same time, we have continued to make significant improvements to the NDIS.

The reform package will deliver on the final elements of the Productivity Commission's original design for the NDIS, and make it simpler, faster, fairer and more flexible for participants, and their families and carers. It includes the implementation of the Government's response to the 2019 independent Review of the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 (Tune Review) and our commitment to implement the NDIS Participant Service Guarantee.

These reforms will help deliver on the promise of the NDIS - to provide Australians with a permanent and significant disability true choice and control over a flexible support package to achieve their goals.
The Government has committed $2 million for the Commonwealth Ombudsman to oversee the NDIA' s performance in meeting the standards set out in the Guarantee, which will be made publically available.
Further information about reforms is available in the NDIS Reforms - Information Paper on the Department of Social Services website:

www.dss.gov.au/disability-and-carers-programs-services-for-people-with-disability-national-disability-insurance-scheme-2019-review-of-the-ndis-act-and-the-new-ndis-participant-service-guarantee/ndis-reforms-information-paper

With regard to your request for anyone dealing with a NDIS participant or representative being fully trained in the disability being discussed, the NDIA provides training and guidance through a structured and tailored induction program and an ongoing training structure to support its planners in their reasonable and necessary decision making. In addition, the NDIA employs a diverse range of staff from different backgrounds including allied and specialist health professionals and both people with lived experience and living with disabilities.
Subject Matter Experts have been appointed by the NDIA within the Access, Planning and Advisory teams to strengthen decisions about participant supports.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Mr Robert (Petition No. EN2268)
COVID-19: Travel Restrictions
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 15 March 2021 concerning petition EN2280, requesting the Australian Government to lift the international travel ban for those who can provide proof of vaccination and a negative COVID-19 test from seven days prior to departure.

I acknowledge the COVID-19 pandemic has brought unprecedented challenges for many people and I note the concerns raised by the petition around the potential impact that this pandemic, and the associated restrictions, can have on the mental health of Australians. The Government shares this concern. I encourage the public to visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'looking after your mental health during coronavirus', as we continue to navigate the ongoing effects of the global pandemic.

The human biosecurity emergency period under the Biosecurity Act 2015 is currently in place until 17 June 2021. All changes to the human biosecurity emergency period are made on the advice of Australia's Chief Medical Officer and the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. The current medical evidence establishes that COVID-19 is continuing to pose a severe and immediate threat to human health on a significant scale, both internationally and domestically.

Whilst the Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of vaccine preventable diseases, vaccination in Australia is not mandatory. People, parents and carers maintain the right and option to choose whether to receive a vaccination or to vaccinate their children.

Additionally, the primary objective of the vaccine program is to reduce the risk of developing serious disease if a person is infected. Early efficacy data released to date has primarily demonstrated that vaccination prevents development of disease if infected with SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19), at least in the short term. More data is required to determine whether these vaccines also prevent vaccinated individuals from transmitting the virus to others and this is a primary consideration in relation to opening borders.

Based on the expert medical advice, mandatory quarantine with COVID-19 testing at frequent intervals is currently considered the best strategy for incoming travellers and has been a key pillar of Australia's response to COVID-19. Combined with other measures including high testing rates, social distancing and strong localised response, mandatory hotel quarantine has resulted in comparatively low numbers of cases in Australia compared to the rest of the world.

In order to protect the safety of Australians while they are overseas, the Government also takes into account expert public health advice according to peak international body, the World Health Organization (WHO). At this point in time the WHO does not advise states and territories to introduce proof of vaccination as a requirement for travel.

Instead, the recommendation is that combined measures such as those outlined above remain critical while there is global variation in access to a COVID-19 vaccine and while more data are required to understand the impact of vaccination on virus transmission.

The Government is considering mechanisms for recognising an international immunisation certificate for COVID-19 and potential alternate entry and quarantine arrangements for returning Australians who may have been vaccinated. These considerations are based on the expert medical advice on vaccination effectiveness and on how best to manage the ongoing risk of transmission from international arrivals.

With respect to diagnostic testing, Australia is fortunate to be supported by an expert and extensive network of public and private laboratories with the capability, capacity and appropriate accreditation to detect SARS-CoV-2. However, no single or combination of tests at present are sensitive, timely and reliable enough to detect a person incubating the infection. After initial infection with SARS-CoV-2, it takes a number of days for viral replication to produce enough genetic material to be detected by Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test. This occurs roughly two to-three days before symptoms become apparent. Testing during the incubation period may return a negative result, even when an individual is infected with SARS-CoV-2.

The major risks with relying on a solution like testing seven days prior to departure is failing to detect an infected passenger who is incubating COVID-19 or of being infected in those seven days. Travel restrictions and mandatory quarantine are considered a reasonable risk mitigation strategy for travellers who are incubating COVID-19, and therefore may not have tested positive to a COVID-19 test before entering and/or departing Australia.

Noting the above, all travellers to Australia, must present evidence of a negative COVID-19 Reverse Transcription Polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test result, where the test was conducted 72 hours or less prior to the scheduled departure time of their flight (or first flight if the passenger has one or more connecting flights booked for travel to Australia). This provides an additional risk mitigation strategy that is in addition to, not a replacement for, 14-day managed quarantine. To note, people who have been vaccinated with the COVID-19 vaccine are still required to undertake the PCR test prior to travel. The most up-to-date information for international travellers to Australia, can be found at my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'Coronavirus (COVID-19) FAQs - international travellers to Australia'.
I wish to assure you that the Government regularly reviews the international travel restrictions to ensure their appropriateness in terms of global and local epidemiology.

The Government is committed to opening up travel with other low risk countries as soon as the health advice says it is safe to do so. While these measures are regrettable, they are necessary to protect the health of Australians.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Health
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 16 March 2021 concerning petition EN23l6.
COVID-19 has the ability to cause high levels of morbidity and mortality, with severe or fatal outcomes generally more common among elderly cases or those with comorbid conditions.

Regrettably, 909 Australians have died from COVID-19. These deaths were predominately due to outbreaks in aged care facilities and cases among older populations that occurred during July and August 2020.

For all cases since the beginning of the pandemic, 14 per cent have been admitted to hospital, noting that this hospitalisation figure requires cautious interpretation as data is not complete. In addition, a case may be hospitalised for isolation purposes meaning their hospitalisation may not reflect severity of illness. According to sentinel surveillance data, 19 per cent of hospitalised patients were admitted to the intensive care unit. 51 cases (or 91 per cent) of those who died in intensive care units had one or more comorbidities. Australia's case fatality rate has remained stable at 3.1 per cent and, at the time of writing, there have been no reported COVID-19 related deaths in Australia for 2021.

Comorbidities, such as obesity, are serious public health challenges in their own right. That is why, in June 2019, I announced the development of a 10-year National Preventative Health Strategy (Strategy). The Strategy will aim to help Australians improve their health at all stages of life, through early intervention, targeting risk factors, better information and addressing the broader causes for poor health and wellbeing.

Over 6,000 people have been consulted on the Strategy's development since September 2019, including eight topic-specific workshops and a national online consumer survey. The draft National Preventive Health Strategy opened for consultation on 5 March 2021 with consultation closing on 19 April 2021.

The draft Strategy considers the root causes of poor health, including social, environmental and structural factors. It also sets out the approach for mobilising a prevention system and identifies seven focus areas to boost prevention action in the first years of the strategy, namely:
reducing tobacco use
improving access to and the consumption of a healthy diet
increasing physical activity
increasing cancer screening and prevention
improving immunisation coverage
reducing alcohol and other drug harm
protecting mental health.
The consultation, including the draft Strategy, can be accessed via my Department's website at: www.consultations.health.gov.au.

Concerning specific comorbidities, the Australian Government recognises the burden of disease attributable to poor diets, overweight and obesity and related chronic conditions. Supporting Australians to eat a healthy, balanced diet and be more active are complex public health issues with multiple contributing factors (individual, social and environmental).

Addressing these issues in Australia requires a multi-faceted, community wide approach delivered through a range of initiatives and organisations. The Government is committed to actively educate, support and encourage Australians to adopt and maintain a healthy lifestyle, rather than introducing additional regulations.
The Government undertakes a wide range of initiatives to encourage and· support Australians to adopt a healthier lifestyle, including:
the Healthy Weight Guide website - helps Australians achieve and maintain a healthy weight and address obesity and overweight
Health Star Rating system - a front of pack food labelling system which rates the overall nutritional profile of packaged food

Healthy Food Partnership - a non-regulatory, collaborative forum between the Government, food industry and public health groups which is aimed at tackling obesity, encouraging healthy eating and empowering food companies to make positive changes to their products

Australian Dietary Guidelines (ADG) - which provide evidence-based advice on the types and amounts of foods that Australians should eat to achieve and maintain a healthy weight, meet nutrient requirements and reduce the risk of diet related chronic diseases

Sugars labelling - there is work underway to consider changing the way sugars are labelled on food packages to help Australians make informed choices in support of the recommendations in the ADGs. Further information is provided on the Food Standards Australia New Zealand website at: www.foodstandards.gov.au/consumer/labelling/Pages/Sugar-labelling.aspx

Australia's Physical Activity and Sedentary Behaviour Guidelines and 24-Hour Movement Guidelines - are available for all life-stages and provide guidance on what duration and intensity of physical activity and what sedentary behaviour is appropriate for each age group to benefit their overall health and wellbeing
Healthy Heart Initiative - aims to increase support for people to improve physical activity levels and achieve healthy lifestyles to help prevent chronic disease
Healthy Pregnancies initiative - aims to support those who are pregnant and their partners to manage their weight, improve their diet and increase physical activity before and during pregnancy.

Concerning smoking, the Government's National Tobacco Strategy and National Drug Strategy guides our work to reduce smoking rates in Australia. Initiatives include education programs and campaigns, such as culturally appropriate smoking cessation activities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Further, the Government's tobacco control regulatory framework includes tobacco plain packaging and graphic health warnings, and bans on tobacco advertising and promotion, as well as additional support for smokers to quit, policies to reduce the affordability of tobacco products, and measures to prevent and minimise the illicit tobacco trade.

With regard to alcohol, in November 2019, all Australian governments endorsed the National Alcohol Strategy, which aims to prevent and minimise alcohol-related harm among individuals, families and communities. This strategy describes the nationally agreed goal of harm minimisation, and outlines agreed national priority areas of focus and policy options. Additionally, in November 2018 the Government launched the Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder (FASD) Strategic Action Plan which aims to reduce the prevalence of FASD and the impact it has on individuals, families, carers and communities.

Concerning COVID-19, the Government has made a total investment of $6.3 billion in Australia's COVID-19 health response. This includes over $3 billion in vaccine purchase and nearly $2 billion in vaccine roll-out requirements such as workforce funding to states and territories, health professional training, vaccine delivery and supporting digital systems.

On 21 February 2021, the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, launched Australia's COVID-19 vaccination program. From 22 March 2021, over 100 GP respiratory clinics and 1,000 general practices joined the COVID-19 vaccination program under Phase 1B of vaccine program roll-out. Among the priority groups in Phase lB are adults with a specified medical condition and adults with a severe disability who have a specified underlying medical condition.
There are also some important steps every Australian can and should take to help reduce the spread of COVID-19 and to protect those who are most at risk. These include:
maintaining physical distancing of 1.5 metres whenever and wherever we can
maintaining good hand washing and cough/sneeze hygiene
staying home when we are unwell, and getting tested if we have respiratory symptoms or a fever
having businesses develop and sustain COVID-safe plans for workplaces.

These practices, in combination other measures such as Australia's effective testing and quarantine regime, are helping protect the health and wellbeing of all Australians, including those with comorbidities.
Thank you for bringing this petition and its concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
JobKeeper Payment: Tourism Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 March 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Standing Committee on Petitions (EN2320) - a request for a further extension to the JobKeeper Payment and additional support for the travel and tourism sectors. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The JobKeeper Payment was designed as a national scheme, to apply consistently across a broad range of businesses and industry sectors. As such, the scheme was not intended to apply individual criteria for the payment to any specific sector or group of businesses. On 21 July 2020, in response to the ongoing economic impacts of COVID-19, the Australian Government announced an extension to the JobKeeper Payment for a further six months until 28 March 2021 with the payment rates tapered down to help businesses adjust and gradually transition from the scheme.

The JobKeeper Payment was always intended to be a temporary program designed to support confidence and get businesses back up and running as soon as possible. JobKeeper is just one part of the Government's economic response to support Australians during COVID-19. It was designed to deliver support quickly and at scale and it has achieved its objective of keeping businesses in business and Australians in jobs. JobKeeper has supported nearly half of Australian businesses and one-third of all workers.

On 11 March 2021, in recognition that certain sectors would need some additional assistance, the Government announced a further $1.2 billion in targeted support for the tourism and aviation sectors. The package includes a mix of half-price airline tickets and direct support to keep planes in the air and aviation workers in jobs. Increasing domestic tourism will help businesses along the supply chain including hotels, cafes and restaurants and tour operators get back to normal trading. Through the Tourism Aviation Network Support (TANS) Program, discount ticket prices will be available on more than 45,000 fares per week. Australians will be able to access these discount fares to 14 tourism regions particularly hurt by COVID-19 for travel through to the end of September 2021.

The Government will provide an additional $133 million to extend the Consumer Travel Support Program for three months to support travel agents. This brings the total level of targeted assistance to $261 million, which will help to sustain the travel sector as it supports travellers adjust to COVID-safe travel.

The Government has also extended existing supports, including the $50 million Business Events Grants Program to provide confidence to the sector and the $94.6 million Zoos and Aquarium program to support zoos, aquariums and wildlife parks to maintain their animal populations.

The Government also announced that it will expand and extend its existing SME Guarantee Scheme as part of its commitment to support up to $40 billion in lending to small and medium enterprises. The SME Recovery Loan Scheme will continue to provide assistance to firms that have recently been on JobKeeper and will benefit from an increased government guarantee, allowing lenders to offer a repayment holiday of up to 24 months, longer loan terms, larger loan sizes and the ability for borrowers to refinance existing debt.
The vaccine roll-out is also gathering pace, supporting domestic borders to remain open and providing greater certainty for people to travel for both business and leisure purposes.
For further information on the COVID-19 tourism support plan, please visit:
www.austrade.gov.au/Australian/Tourism/Tourism-and-business.
Further information on the Government's COVID-19 support for the aviation sector can be found at:
www.infrastructure.gov.au/aviation/index.aspx#aviation.
For further information on the Small and Medium Enterprise Recovery Loan Scheme, please visit:
www.treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/sme-guarantee-scheme.
For further information on the Business Events Grants program, please visit:
www.austrade.gov.au/Australian/Tourism/Tourism-and-business/Grants/business-events-exhibitor-grants-program.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COVID-19: Australians Overseas
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 19 March 2021 regarding Petition No. EN2323 regarding the Government's efforts to assist Australians return during the pandemic.

Supporting the return of vulnerable Australians from overseas remains one of the Government' s highest priorities. We are working with airlines, Commonwealth agencies and States and Territories to assist Australians to return and to access available commercial flights. Since March 2020, over 490,000 Australians have returned to Australia. During this period, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) has supported over 42,700 Australians return, including over 17,000 people on 120 government facilitated flights. As at 31 March 2021, almost 120,000 Australians have returned since National Cabinet met on 18 September 2020.

The Government continues to take a multi-pronged approach to facilitate the return of Australians. This includes helping Australians to access scheduled commercial flights under the existing flight caps, arranging government facilitated commercial flights above the caps, providing financial assistance to vulnerable Australians through the Overseas Financial Assistance program as well as providing information and consular assistance.

Based on expert medical advice, mandatory quarantine is the best strategy to help people return while protecting the health of all Australians. On 5 March 2020, the Commonwealth and Northern Territory Governments reached agreement to increase the capacity of the Centre for National Resilience at Howard Springs after the end of the cyclone season in the Northern Territory. This will increase the capacity of Howard Springs from 850 persons per fortnight to 2,000 persons per fortnight with a ramp up from late April 2021, subject to capital works, and full capacity between June and December 2021. The Centre for National Resilience is the Commonwealth Government's response to the National Cabinet commissioned National Review of Hotel Quarantine conducted by Ms Jane Halton, AO PSM. This approach does not include using detention centres as quarantine facilities, reflecting the significant and complex medical and logistical resources required to safely quarantine vulnerable Australians arriving from abroad.

The Commonwealth Government will continue to support repatriation flights for Australians through to the end of 2021, as required. Further flights are planned from the United Kingdom, South Africa and India in the coming weeks.
Throughout COVID-19, Australia has successfully balanced the safety of our community at home whilst ensuring significant numbers of Australians overseas can return.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Small Business: Insurance
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 March 2021, originally directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, concerning Petition EN2326 and the availability of public liability insurance for small businesses. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Government is aware that accessing adequate public liability insurance has been particularly challenging for some adventure tourism, amusement park and caravan park businesses. This was highlighted by the Australian Small Business and Family Enterprise Ombudsman's (ASBFEO) insurance inquiry report released in December 2020.

The ASBFEO report's recommendations have substantial implications for the sustainability and affordability of insurance, which the Government will consider as it continues to monitor business insurance markets.

The Government notes the Insurance Council of Australia's recent announcement that it would undertake a review covering issues of insurance access and affordability. A consultation paper is expected to be released in coming weeks, with a final report expected in mid-2021. The Government welcomes insurers proactively considering options to contribute to growth and the national economic recovery, particularly with a focus on industry-led solutions.
I trust this information will be of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Insurance
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 March 2021 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning a petition (EN2368) received to establish a reinsurance pool for northern Australia to address availability issues in public liability insurance. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

I acknowledge the petitioner's concerns regarding access to public liability insurance. However, the policy offerings an insurer provides is a commercial decision for insurers to make, based on a number of factors that influence an insurer's appetite for, and capacity to take on, a client's risk. Similarly , the setting of insurance premiums are influenced by these factors. To discuss the factors used to determine policy offerings and premiums, the petitioner may wish to contact the Insurance Council of Australia (ICA) on 1300 728 228.

The public liability insurance market in Australia is affected by each level of government. At the state level, legislation covering civil liability generally requires that businesses address injuries arising from negligence in a timely and fair manner. Public liability insurance puts businesses in the position to fulfil that mandated requirement.

State law may also require professionals or certain types of business to hold insurance as a condition of licensing. In the case where a business requires a state-issued license to operate as is the case for some tourism operators, then it is also expected that the business has a current public liability insurance policy in place to the satisfaction of the relevant state body. Local councils may also stipulate that a business must bold public liability insurance before contracting or providing a permit.

I would suggest the petitioner raise this issue with their state government and explore, potentially through an insurance broker, whether there are any further actions the petitioner could take to lower the risk profile of their business to reduce the costs of cover.

More generally, regarding the costs and availability of insurance in northern Australia, in 20I7, the Australian Government directed the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to conduct a wide-ranging inquiry into the supply of residential building (home), contents and strata insurance in northern Australia. On 28 December 2020, the ACCC released its final report, details of which can be found online, at: www.accc.gov.au/focus-areas/inquiries-ongoing/northem-australia-insurance-inquiry. The Government is currently considering the recommendations in the ACCC 's final report.

As part of its response to the Royal Commission into National Natural Disaster Arrangements, the Government is establishing a national resilience, relief and recovery agency to coordinate and align Australia's national capability to build resilience, better prepare for natural disasters, and recover from all hazards. The Government will also establish Resilience Services, a climate and disaster risk information service to support our national preparedness, response, relief, recovery and resilience efforts. These measures will contribute to addressing the underlying drivers of insurance affordability issues in the region.

The issue of insurance availability and affordability is a matter that requires action from the Commonwealth as well as state governments and industry. The ACCC' s final report recommended that states abolish stamp duty on home, contents and strata insurance products. This recommendation requires the action of state and territory governments. If the petitioner would like more information about the Queensland Government's position on this recommendation, the petitioner should contact their state Member of Parliament.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar

subdebateinfo.title: JobKeeper Payment: Arts and Entertainment Industry

p.span: JobKeeper Payment: Arts and Entertainment Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 March 2021 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petitions (EN2395) - a further extension to the JobKeeper Payment for the arts and entertainment sectors. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The JobKeeper Payment was designed as a national scheme, to apply consistently across a broad range of Australian businesses and industry sectors. As such, the scheme was not intended to apply individual criteria for the payment to any specific sector or group of businesses. On 21 July 2020, in response to the ongoing economic impacts of COVID-19, the Australian Government announced an extension to the JobKeeper Payment for a further six months until 28 March 2021 with the payment rates tapered down to help businesses adjust and gradually transition from the scheme.

The JobKeeper Payment was always intended to be a temporary program designed to support confidence and get businesses back up and running as soon as possible. It was designed to deliver support quickly and at scale and it has achieved its objective of keeping businesses in business and Australians in jobs. JobKeeper has supported nearly half of Australian businesses and one-third of all workers.

JobKeeper is just one part of the Government's economic response to support Australians during COVID-19. In 2020, in recognition of the economic, social and national importance of the cultural and creative sector, the Government announced almost $800 million in extra arts and entertainment funding. This is on top of a record annual investment of around $750 million in core funding, and on top of the substantial support provided to the sector through whole of economy measures.
The Government has continued to monitor the impacts of COVID-19 to ensure that policy responses are timely, appropriate and proportionate to address the challenges posed by the pandemic.

On 25 March 2021, the Government announced a $125 million extension of the Restart Investment to Sustain and Expand (RISE) Fund, available until 31 December 2021. This is in addition to the $75 million the Government has allocated to the Fund to date. For further information on the RISE funding visit: www.arts.gov.au/funding-and-support/rise-fund.

The Government also announced a further $10 million to Support Act to allow them to respond quickly and effectively to the continuing needs of artists, crew and music workers including sound and lighting technicians, managers, booking agents, promoters, venue workers and roadies still affected by COVID-19. This is in addition to the $10 million provided to Support Act announced in April last year. For further information on this support visit: supportact.org.au/get-help/.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COMMITTEES

subdebateinfo.title: Social Policy and Legal Affairs Committee

p.span: Social Policy and Legal Affairs Committee
Report

Mr WALLACE (Fisher) (09:47): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs, I present the committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled Inquiry into family, domestic and sexual violence, together with the minutes of proceedings.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Mr WALLACE: by leave—The scourge of family, domestic and sexual violence is sadly all too familiar. Since this inquiry commenced in June of last year, more than 40 women will have been murdered at the hands of a current or former partner. Countless other women, children and men will have experienced non-lethal family violence and abuse. Sometimes we see the names and faces of the victims on our screens, but more often than not family violence remains hidden. What we do know is that the impact of this shocking violence and abuse is profound and long-lasting on victim-survivors, on their families and friends and on the very fabric of our society.

Recognising the need to stem this violence, governments across Australia came together in 2009 to establish the National Plan to Reduce Violence Against Women and their Children. Many achievements have flowed from the national plan, including the creation of Our Watch, the Stop it at the Start awareness campaign and national support services such as 1800 RESPECT. Importantly, through the national plan the community has begun to grapple with the cultural change that is necessary to prevent violence from occurring in the first place. More people are now willing to speak up and to challenge the attitudes and behaviours that lead to violence. However, there is much more work to be done. Despite significant investments from governments of all jurisdictions and all political persuasions, it is clear that the national plan has not achieved its objective of a significant and sustained reduction in violence against women and their children. As a nation, we can do better and we must do better.

This inquiry was an opportunity to reflect on the successes and shortcomings of the national plan, to hear from experts in the field about what has and what has not worked and to identify opportunities to ensure that the next national plan leads to a meaningful reduction in family, domestic and sexual violence. It should go without saying that the committee took this task very seriously. The committee carefully considered around 300 submissions and held 90 hours of public hearings over the course of 16 days. The committee also held to in camera hearings where it heard from individuals about their lived experience of family, domestic and sexual violence.

In this report, the committee has made 88 bipartisan recommendations which seek to inform the development of the next national plan. These recommendations are wide ranging but can be grouped under five main themes. First, the next national plan should involve a more uniform approach across Australia but one that recognises the many different forms of family violence and the diversity of victim-survivors and perpetrators. This should include the development of a uniform national definition of family, domestic and sexual violence that takes account of non-physical forms of violence, such as coercive control, financial abuse and technology facilitated abuse.

Second, the next national plan must seek to engender a culture of accountability while also providing more support to the specialist family violence workforce. All Australian governments should be held to account through hard targets. Similarly, while the committee has called for more secure funding for frontline services, ongoing monitoring and evaluation is critical to better understand what works, what does not and why. To support these recommendations, the committee has proposed to establish a national commissioner who would have independent oversight of the next national plan.

Third, education is critical. There remains a need for greater awareness and understanding of the many forms of family, domestic and sexual violence and the causes, the impacts of this violence and the ways in which it can be prevented. The committee has recommended a continued focus on primary prevention; the rollout of universal, age-appropriate respectful relationships and sexual consent education; and measures to help workers in the social services sector identify and respond to violence.

Fourth, in the response to family, domestic, and sexual violence, the welfare of victim-survivors and their children should be paramount. The next national plan should seek to improve victim-survivors' access to specialist services as well as housing, legal aid and financial assistance. The committee has recommended improvements to risk identification, including ensuring that coercive control is recognised as not only a form of abuse in its own right but also a precursor to severe physical abuse and, in fact, homicide. The committee has also made recommendations for improving services to victim-survivors in times of natural disasters, informed by our experiences during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Finally, the next national plan must continue to hold perpetrators to account for their use of violence. This should include increased penalties for breaches of domestic violence orders and improved information sharing about perpetrators. The committee has also recommended more research to better understand why perpetrators choose to use violence and an increased focus on evidence-based programs to change perpetrator behaviour.

In closing, I would like to thank members of the committee. I would like to thank many organisations and individuals who have contributed evidence to the inquiry. In particular, thank you to the victim-survivors who shared their experiences with the committee. We acknowledge your courage in speaking out and advocating for change. The hard work and dedication of the members of the committee, many of whom are in the chamber this morning, was, quite frankly, very commendable. This was, in some cases, quite harrowing work, and the work that the members did really speaks volumes. It was an 88-recommendation bipartisan report. I'm very, very proud to stand here and say that this is parliament at its best, when we really do recognise that the line which runs up the centre of this floor doesn't exist when it comes to the welfare and security of victims-survivors of domestic violence. The committee hopes that this report will contribute to our collective national effort to end family, domestic and sexual violence. It is perpetrators who are responsible for their use of violence, but everyone has a role in speaking up to make change and to stop violence before it starts.

The government has already acted in the budget on a number of these 88 recommendations. I'm very pleased to see that, on a number of those 88 recommendations, the government is taking a very leaning forward approach. It announced some of those things just last night, so we are on the road towards zero. The committee implores all Australian governments to consider this report carefully and to act on its recommendations with urgency. I commend the report to the House.

Ms CLAYDON (Newcastle) (09:56): by leave—As the deputy chair of the Social Policy and Legal Affairs Committee I am very pleased to rise in the House today and speak on this report, following our rather extensive inquiry over the last eight to nine months of this parliament into family, domestic and sexual violence.

At the outset, I want to thank the chair for his leadership in helping ensure that this committee stayed on track at a time when we were in the midst of COVID. Like all committee work had to, we were able to shift to digital platforms in order to take vital evidence on an issue that has now really become such an urgent one. It has been for a long time, but family, domestic and sexual violence in Australia is now well and truly in the government spotlight.

I'm delighted to be able to table this report. It is a weighty tome, and there are 88 solid bipartisan recommendations in it. I won't go through each of those; I think the chair has done an excellent job in mapping out some of those broad themes. On behalf of all the Labor members of the committee I sincerely thank the chair and our government colleagues, who made great contributions in ensuring that this report was the best it could be.

I also want to give a shout-out to the extraordinary efforts of the secretariat. People may not realise that we were actually running two major concurrent reports. We were also doing a report into housing and homelessness—another national crisis in Australia—at the same time as our work on family, domestic and sexual violence. The secretariat were terribly underresourced and overstretched at the time, and we were able to get one additional staff person to help crack through two really big inquiries. We are yet to table the housing and homeless inquiry; that's yet to come.

In addition to the secretariat, I want to acknowledge the contributions from victims-survivors who gave especially powerful testimony to the committee. We are forever indebted to them for sharing their experiences of family, domestic and sexual violence. I also thank those frontline services and organisations that made contributions on the most pressing issue facing us as a country, at a time when they were probably the most stretched and pushed.

As the chair said, we had more than 350 submissions, 47 confidential submissions, 16 days of inquiries and 90 hours of evidence over many months. In addition to what the chair mapped out, I would just like to say that these are very strong bipartisan commitments—recommendations. I slipped because I want to see them become government commitments. I will acknowledge that there were measures in the budget last night. But, before I give too many pats on the back, I want to say that this is off the back of women and children in Australia making their voices heard, loud and clear, year after year after year until, finally, enough was enough. The evidence taken by our committee was absolutely unequivocal. The scale of this problem is greater than either the resources or the resolve that the government has committed to date. We would want to see these recommendations endorsed, wholly, by the government, because that is what's needed to face up to the challenge and to finally embrace the capacity and the obligation that we have, as a Commonwealth, to actually do so much more.

As good as this report is, I could point to another eight reports that have been tabled in this parliament over eight years asking for urgent action on this issue. I'm not going to do too much self-congratulation just at this point. When I see the full weight of government behind these 88 recommendations then I'll feel like the job might well have been done. Many of the recommendations made by this committee, as I said, have been made by previous committees. They could have been implemented by the government many years ago. That failure has had some very real consequences. The economic cost of violence against women and children in Australia is estimated to be $26 billion a year. Victims and survivors bear more than half of that cost, as well as the long-term social, health and psychological damage. It's a very heavy burden. Our failure to act on family, domestic and sexual violence, over many years now, has resulted in a very heavy burden for women and children in this nation.

The government must not ignore this report. The recommendations should be implemented immediately. The government doesn't have to wait till the next national plan to implement the majority of these recommendations. The Labor members on the committee are calling for urgent action to be taken. A crucial test of this government will be, indeed, how quickly it responds to this report and how willing it is to enact the recommendations. It cannot sit on the shelves gathering dust like the other eight reports over the last eight years have done.
Mr WALLACE (Fisher) (10:03): I move:
That the House take note of the report.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Rob Mitchell ): In accordance with standing order 39(d), the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
Reference to Federation Chamber
Mr WALLACE (Fisher) (10:04): I move:
That the order of the day be referred to the Federation Chamber for debate.
Question agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Joint Committee

p.span: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Joint Committee
Report

Mr WALLACE (Fisher) (10:04): On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the committee's report, entitled Inquiry into Australia's defence relationships with Pacific island nations.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Mr WALLACE: by leave—Australia is historically and indelibly linked to its neighbours in the Pacific islands. Our shared history of endurance and mutual assistance during times of major international conflict, natural disaster, climate change and pandemic has forged links with our Pacific island family which go beyond statehood and diplomacy. Our people-to-people links forged over centuries are at the core of this deep understanding, and defence relationships play a significant role in creating and maintaining this unique connection.

Defence and security challenges faced in the Pacific are now more prevalent and complex than ever before.
